reviewText:
After having played this game for a fair share of hours (~300 by now) I feel like I am able to give an acceptable review.

Updated: With the major update for Wakfu on the 9th September 2014 there was quite something added and I will try my best to include it as well.

What's Wakfu?
Wakfu is a turn based Strategy-MMO that, to me, feels like a love-child between Ragnarok Online and Fire Emblem. And I love it.

The player is able to impact the actual economy of the world, meaning that animals, plants and trees have to be taken care of and replanted to keep the natural balance.
If that is not the case a species will go endangered or even extinct. Each nation's political system is governed by players that were voted into their ranks by others. They set the law, breaking those will result in you becoming an outlaw. Players joining the guards of their nation can hunt down outlaws and put them in jail to atone for their sins. Justice!

The graphics may seem not up to date on first glance, however when playing the game one will notice that there is actually a high level of detail in everything.

To sum up what I like and dislike:
Pros:
+ Free2Play: There is a Cash shop, however it only sells cosmetic items or Sidekicks that can also be acquired with ingame gold (Kama) instead. You can get your hands on anything without paying a cent as there are many players that sell cash shop items or currency.
+ 15 classes with three elemental specialisations to choose from.
+ 17 professions and you can master them all in one character at the same time if you want to.
+ Strategic gameplay as your composition and line-up can determine success or fail.
+ Up to two mercenaries (sidekicks) that can help you in solo and even teamplay to substitute missing players/friends
+ Economical System depending on players
(Fun fact, the money that circulates through servers is player crafted too)
+ Nations (4) and a political system governed by players
(Nations can wage war against each other)
Updated - There is now a fifth Bandit Nation players can join.
+ Many secret places or recipes(!) one can discover in the world that will reward you handsomely.
+ can be played casually
+ It's damn cute

Cons:
- The starting area (lvl 1-10): Astrub is not a fun place. You can get out of it luckily in less than an half hour and join a nation. However it wants you to do a few quests that are not fun to do in my opinion and probably put-off a fair share of people before they even really ever started the game.
Updated - The whole starting Area was revamped into something much better!
- Steam and Wakfu: If you wish to play the game via steam, you do not necessarily need an Ankama account, HOWEVER I highly recommend one to you. As you will not be able to play Wakfu whenever steam has connections issues to your server.
Updated - You are now able to login with your steam account on the Ankama website that allows you to have all conveniences Ankama Account users have. The server connection problems however may remain.
- Region bound servers
- Java: the game runs on java and everyone who played minecraft knows that java's RAM allocation is not great by default for games and you will need to allocate more by customising yours under your system settings. Else after hours of gameplay your wakfu client may slowly start to lag more and more until you relog.
- Positioning and Terrain: in rare occasions certain big tiles of the map like pillars or similar make it hard to actually click behind" them to position your character there.
- Support: Even though I have had an okay experience with the support myself so far
date: everyone that I have met that had/has severe problems ingame has huge troubles with the support
recommended:
to the point it feels about non-existent.
- Grindy: Not a problem to me but I know there's a fair share of people that dislike grinding.

I personally love it and have to admit I have not yet had a game like this and thus it is nice to enjoy something different.
So I would give it an 8/10

p.s. It has a great anime-like cartoon with two seasons that you should watch!"

reviewText:
As a particular lover of turn based games and role playing games in general, I decided to give a try to this MMO. Once he landed on Steam, I got into the beta and started to enjoy the universe of the World of the Twelve.
Despite having few hours compared to many other players, I can say this game is actually enjoyable and well made. However, there are some factors that could lead some people to avoid this title for various reasons. Let's analize every detail of the game. If you want to skip the wall of text, just go to the end, where there's a short version.

GRAPHICS

The graphic is 2,5D Cartoonish - Style, similar to animes. I like it, but somebody may not appreciate it. Colourful environments, characters and enemies (aka mobs).
However, sometimes you'll encouter a bunch of graphical bugs like invisible enemies, sidekicks not appearing, your avatar being nude (yes, you heard it right!) or colors that make your eyes to cry blood (phosphorescent enemies).
At last, talking about the active parts of the game, while the enemies are well made and be distinghuished between their gender, the characters (not including npcs) tend to be more feminine. If you give a try to the game, you'll notice that even the males look like females.

SOUND

There isn't so much to say about the sound. Each sector has its own, enjoyable track, including islands. The only bug you may encounter is an infinite loop after the dungeon of Zeppelantern.

GAMEPLAY

Here we come, in the longest part of the review. Let's start with the choice of your avatar. You can choose between 15 different races, each one with its peculiarities and abilities. You can even decide if you want to have a male or a female, with the exception of the foggernaut (it's a robot!).
Regarding the gamestyle, it's a turn - based game during the fights against the mobs and the other players, while it's in real time during your journeys, explorations, harvests and crafts. Yes, because in this game you don't only get experience by killing tons of monsters or by completing dungeons you may access with specific keys and after you reach certain levels, but you can also produce your own items by collecting the resources in the environment and by crafting them in specific workshops.
You can also decide to group with some other people (or recruit up to 2 sidekicks) to face evil forces or stronger enemies that you couldn't defeat if you were alone.
Now the negative aspects of the gameplay. The tutorial itself is kinda crappy, made not properly because it teaches you only some parts of the game. It's useful just to know how's the interface, how to fight and how to collect and plant the enemies in the field in order to generate a wave of monsters to fight. Ah yeah, also to get the starting experience when you'll start with the real game itself.
The second most negative aspect is the interface. It isn't intuitive at the beginning, you can't move nor rotate the camera while you're in real time (but you can zoom in and out), while in the turn-based combats you can move it in a way the game doesn't explain. In fact, it doesn't tell you that holding the right button of the mouse and moving the cursor on the borders of your screen will allow you to see the entire battlefield.
And, at last, the quest system of the main missions is kinda...lame. You don't get involved in the main story and you do just some random quests in order to get experience and your first and only free sidekick. But, considering how's the game, you don't play it surely for the main quests.

GAME SYSTEM

The game is totally f2p. You're granted access to every part of the game (with the exception of the last 2 islands introduced not long ago), you can choose a nation at level 18 and do every kind of job. The nation system will allow you to player versus player fights and each nation has its own peculiarities. You're granted a free sidekick you can keep forever with every single character you make (until 5 per account) plus a free additional sidekick with a weekly rotation system.
The real money allows you to buy the sidekicks and keep them forever, cosmetics, costumes and booster packs that let you drop more loot and get more experience (in a small percentage however) plus the access to the last 2 optional islands. However, these zones are reserved for characters around level 140+.

SHORT VERSION

PROS

- 15 races to choose from, with possibility of gender changing, that can reach until level 200.
- Different zones and islands to explore, with a huge variety of enemies
- 4 Nations to choose from, each one with its dominant element and peculiarities.
- PVP, Guilds and PVE system
- Huge quantity of dungeons, with specific dungeons you may find only in a certain nation
- Rewarding system well made
- Great variety of jobs, in harvesting and crafting, letting you to get your own items and to collect kamas (the game currency) fastly
- Colourful graphics
- Good sound system
- Mobs having ehm...sex?

CONS

- Shabby tutorial that teaches few things compared to the real potential.
- Not-so intuitive interface
- Main quests system not involving and realized superficially
- Might be boring if you focus only on getting experience
- Requires a lot of time and patience, 2 things that most people don't own...unfortunately.

I recommend to try this game at least once to every kind of afficionado of rpgs/mmorpgs. However, if you are included in one of the following categories I'm enlisting, just don't play this game:

a) You don't like turn based games
b) The story and the drama in a game is everything for you
c) The graphics is the most important thing for you
d) Anime haters
e) Average Call of Duty player

reviewText:
I have put a lot of time into this game. I admit, it does speak to an extremely small crowd due to the nature of the genre of game + the amount of grind you must devote. I still have a long way to go before max level (Current level 144, max is 170) So you see it does take a LONGGGG time. If you are fans of disgaea/fire emblem/other turn-based strategy game it MAY or MAY NOT be for you. You must not enter the game with the wrong mindset, and you must find others to play with. The content of the game becomes very difficult and without other players to team up with you are going to have a bad time. The community driven aspect of this game is amazing and this game has one of the best communities I've been a part of.

THE BAD:
If you are starting this game you are going to become overwhelmed in which skills to level, and which specialties to level in which order. I admit that does suck, but there are plenty of guides out there for each class. Another thing you should do is actually read the skills instead of just blindly following a guide. I still learn new strategies/perks on my character everyday!

I hope this gives a good representation of the game; My hours speak for me and I love it!

reviewText: Wakfu is a brilliant game. Wakfu has its own taste, its own style. All characters are different, all builds are reliable, all groups are potent. It have some problems today, like economics breaches and balance issues, but all of them will be fixed sooner or later. Graphics, musics and so are just perfect. Wakfu is a game with soul. Yes, this soul is full of grind, but even coop grind is fun in Wakfu. This game has very good potential.

reviewText:
A great game, ruined by non-existent support and a capricious developer team.  Everything about the game is completely fantastic and thoughtful and fills a niche that no other multiplayer game really captures.  I couldn't say enough nice things about it.

All of that comes apart though when you encounter any problems.  Did a glitch eat your stuff?  Tough.  Sending a request to the support group will result in nothing.  Did your class get nerfed right out from under you with no explanation?  Too bad, buy a class change scroll from the cash store for $40, it's your own fault for having played the class.

If the game's developers had any kind of meaningful dialogue with the players instead of acting like the invisible hand of an angry god, if the community staff actually fostered some kind of two-way communication instead of just passing on the sparse edicts from higher-ups, and if the support team had the people and resources to fix problems for players, Wakfu would be amazing.

Instead I warn people against investing their time or money in this game, and it's a terrible shame because it has brilliant potential.

reviewText:
Ok so when I saw this was free to play my first thought was 'Oh great... here we go again, another pay to win or donate your life savings into this game to be decent', but its turning out not to be the case at all.   This game is grindy and takes time, but if you want to just push buttons and feel good about yourself immediately, then this may not be your game and that's OK.  Sometimes however, effort required to do something makes it have more meaning, and if this is your thing you may just like this :D

The fact that I can do more in this Free to Play MMO -without restrictions- than I can when I buy a full version of a Total War Game which then gives me the 'chance' to buy a bunch of DLC, is a commentary in itself (on both games, despite different genre / game type and I am a HUGE Total War fan).

*Items- lots of sense of humor with pets, armor, and misc items.  Sort of like the humor of Borderlands, but not quite.  (There's an NPC in a sewer named Donallangelo who essentially is a pun of Ninja Turtles, and pets like a Ghast have descriptions which read 'I ain't afraid of no ghast!' and so on)  Also, importantly, no restrictions on items that I can tell so far if you are free to play.

*Great community - helpful and teamwork is essential.  Let's face it, many MMOs don't care to pretend about requiring teamwork - it's just login, get achievements, and feel good about pressing the level button.  This game is not that.  It's teamwork, has depth, and requires thought.  If that's not your thing - great!  Don't play.  Leave it for people who do because this makes for a great community that works together.

*Graphics - pretty charming and actually really awesome artwork.

*Class system - did I say there were what, 700 million classes?  Well maybe not THAT many, but at least 16. Yes 16, which if you can count as high as WoW classes, well then this is a LOT compared to many MMOs.  Beyond that, yea it's complicated Oh noes! Don't try! Too hard!"

reviewText:
I would love to give Wakfu an amazing review...I really would. And I would have a couple of months ago, when I was glued to the screen leveling up my Osamoda. Unfortnately, after over 1500 hours, I've come to the conclusion that Wakfu is a huge time-suck with no true, fulfilling end-game.

I have created a huge assortment of characters, trying to figure out the spells and play-styles that suit me. And while I love the handful (five) I have ended up with (Osa, Sac, Masq, Sadida, Elio), they just aren't enough to hold me to the game. Starting a new character means reliving questlines over and again...some of which have not even been finished by the developers...but which sit in your quest log and stare at you...day-in and day-out (the developers are apparently working on these...but who knows how long the questlines have been waiting to be finished up. Instead, they release new holiday material and conveniently ignore gameplay that needs to be addressed). and the monotony of the quests becomes unbearable. Your char is sent across different maps to collect items and talk to various NPC's, and it's a never-ending pace of back-and-forth-back-and-forth. Nothing changes, even though your characters do. Still, quests are all a must-do if you want your char to have special items or open up new areas that are inaccessible otherwise. So, if you take on another character...and then another...expect that you'll be bored to tears speaking to Pappy Pal and chasing after books across Astrub to obtain your dragoturkey.

Speaking of monotony...grinding is almost mandatory if you want to get anywhere. Professions can be ignored for only so long. Leveling each profession up takes a *lot* of time and patience. However, if you want to make kamas, you have to chop wood, pick herbs, trap animals, mine rocks, etc...as selling these items, or crafting with them, is the only way to really make kamas at the market. And the market is difficult to navigate, as searching for a particular item brings up only the cheapest for sale, instead of a list to choose from. This is frustrating for the simple fact that equipment is element based...and you're forced to spend kamas on equipment that you have to change to suit your particular elements...which also requires kamas. Dungeon runs gift you special coins with which to purchase new equipment, but the gear is often so expensive that it's not worth the time it takes to complete said dungeon the twenty or thirty times it takes to acquire said gear. And once acquired, that gear is linked to your character...so forget selling it at the market in hopes of upgrading to something else when the time arrives. Instead, you are forced into a grind of dun-runs. Quite often, the monotony becomes mind-numbing. Who honestly wants to pick 250 herbs or trap 250 animals just to level up a solitary profession one level---especially when each profession has 100 levels.

Each new area opened quickly loses its appeal after battling its monsters and dungeons. I hit level 120 with two of my characters...and I am *still* awaiting something new to come along at level 132. Who knows when that will be. Probably never. My time with this game is quickly drawing to a close.

PVP is, oftentimes, hugely unbalanced. Characters fifty levels over you can attack you (even if you have PVP deactivated), and there is absolutely no chance at making it out alive. And forget fairness. If you manage to combat a character around your level, and win the duel, you can be sure the player will log in with a much higher level char just to hunt you down and attack you---or call their higher level friends to do it for them. And you can be sure that some of the higher levels are strapped to the teeth with the best equipment/gear...courtesy of the cliques formed within guilds and groups. Also, fair warning: during PVP, you will be insulted, and often. If your enemy doesn't like your character or playstyle, expect to be called a plethora of rude names.

And forget if you need help from Ankama. You pretty much have to sacrifice your unborn children to accomplish reporting a technical issue. They want detailed reports and multiple screenshots for each and every problem (no matter how small the problem is), and even after complying...very little is done to fix the problem(s).

I loved this game at first. The graphics and music and spells and char classes are brilliant. But more thought needs to be put into the game and the gameplay. Because, as is, the hours spent in front of Wakfu are just not worth it when all is said and done.

reviewText:
Wakfu is...an experience. I am still going through my experience but from what I've played of it so far I can give a fair and detailed review of it. I will cover it in four sections; tutorial, gameplay, combat and community. I would also like to mention that I used to pay for and play this game when it was still in open beta about four to five years ago.

Tutorial:
The tutorial for Wakfu reminds me very much of the character actors at Didney Worl; they never break character. Your UI can give you all the information you need to break the fourth wall but when it comes time to learn from an NPC they will talk to you, the player, as if you are your character. The NPCs outside of the tutorial follow suit to this.

Ankama has made one class exclusively for the tutorial which, in my mind seems rather pointless. Back in beta the reason I bothered going through the tutorial areas was so I could get a proper feel for my actual class before I committed to playing it. That said, you can opt to skip the tutorial. I wouldn't advise that if you are a brand spanking new player.

Gameplay:
Wakfu is what most people call a grindfest, but there is reason behind it I like to think. Monsters will drop items that are guaranteed to end up being used for something, no matter the level. Gear can either be combined into sets to be sold, worn or even ground into powder which can be refined into runes to improve the gear you use.

Killing mobs and running quests aren't the only thing you can do in this game, you may also pick up professions. All of them in fact, conveniently located in the starter area known as Astrub. With this in mind a lot of players tend to lean towards one or the other based on their mood at the time. I personally rarely fight and would rather just go farm wheat fields.

Combat:
The combat in Wakfu is unique, something I've never seen in an MMORPG. Ever played Final Fantasy Tactics? This is it. You (and your teammates if you brought any) as well as monsters have a set initiative score, which is a stat you can increase. Those with higher initiative go first and you follow along a grid-based system to fight your enemies. Your character has access to a plethera of passive abilities (able to swap them out between battles on the fly as you unlock them), class-specific utility skills and three skill trees, each one has an element (meaning that you will have access to three of the four elements, I advise you to look through them when you make your character even if you haven't unlocked them).

The player versus player content this game provides comes in some different ways, but ultimately ends up the exact same. There are four nations that you may pick from to be your home upon reaching level 15, with the option to join an outlaw nation at level 30... I wouldn't recommend this though and some people get confused. Let me break this down real quick, if you play this game and hit level 30 you'll recieve a quest called Riktus for a Day." Do not complete this quest

reviewText:
6/10

I won't go into all the details or I'll be here all day.

Wakfu is a beautiful turn-based strategy mmorpg with some sandbox elements. With 15 classes that can be built in many ways, you're bound to find one with a play style that you enjoy. Team up with up to 5 others to run dungeons and Ultimate Bosses!

No friends? Ankama have that covered too! With a couple of sidekicks by your side nothing will stop you!


There are 10 craft professions (not including Kama minting) and 6 gathering skills all of which, with some effort, can be leveled to maximum.

The enviroment and politic system are maintained by the players. Everything that happens within these will affect other players in some way. For example, Governers of each nation are players themselves and are voted in by you, the player. Planting too many mobs or plants in an area will disrupt the enviroment, as will killing too many of them. Distrupt the enviroment too much and you'll become an Outlaw! You'll be fair game for any passing Guard or regular Joe to aggro you...


As the game is still in development. There are A LOT of things that are going to be added or changed fairly soon™. Guild verses guild, a revamp of its guard vs outlaw system, a couple of class revamps along with a lot of other brand new content.

The game is extremely grindy at times but that's what you expect of an mmo, and there IS still a kind of subscription system in play, which has been recently renamed to Booster Packs". Subscribers get access to the newest content
hoursPlayed:
+30% kama drops (the currency) and +30% exp along with some other minor things.

As to why I only gave it a 6/10. That is solely down to Customer Support themselves.

The game
voteText: has had and still does have major bugs and issues which may make you reconsider playing. Things such as complete inventory/haven bag wipes and/or characters dissapearing combined with Customer Support ignoring tickets can be very disheartening.\n\nSaying that
helpfulPercent:
these are rare cases and the charm of the game will likely outweigh this. The game is very playable as f2p and I highly recommend playing this game.

Oh Snap xXx
2 years Wakfuing"

reviewText:
Been playing for about 2 years.

It's not bad, but three things bother me immensely:

- Community is very cliquey, very hard to just play with others without them trying to recruit you or straight up use you as a loot wh**e. Which means, they bring you along, but you give them item drops in return to come along. This is probably the worst thing about the Nox (North American) community.

- Ankama in general ignores the North American region in terms of feedback and communication. Which is always hard as foreign companies based in foreign countries have a harder time bonding with the community. The moderators and staff very rarely visit the NA forum. In fact, other than Sabi, we have little to no interaction with them at all.

- Very grindy gameplay; this has been improved a lot very recently, but it is still unbelievably painful to get anywhere. This ties into the first point a lot as well. Progression screeches to a crawl after level 100 and without a dedicated group finder, you're basically solo (unless you have friends that also play) 90% of the time. People even go so far as to multibox 3-6 accounts just to not be alone. Which I suppose is an entirely different level of alone.

All in all; it's not a bad game, it has its moments, but dear god after 2 years, they are only now starting to fix a few glaring issues that have been prevalent since day 1.

My score as a standalone title: 6.5/10.
Compared to most other MMOs: 7.5/10.

Warning: They will try to milk you for as much money as they can get away with.

My reply to their support after being denied for another thing I needed help with. My last request was years ago and they still didn't help me, so it's not like I constantly harrass them for assistance. You win again Ankama, hope that 20 dollars was worth it.

reviewText:
As someone who has spent many hours with both MMO's and Tactical RPG's, this was a pleasant find.

I spent many years playing WoW, Star Wars:TOR, and DCU, but I had come to find myself tired of the formula that MMO's had fallen into. I had basically given up on the genre, as there is very little variation beyond setting. When I saw Wakfu on Steam for the first time, I overlooked it. The artwork was not my favorite, and the name of the game itself didn't draw me in at all. It wasn't until a few days later that I was looking through the games again that I decided to look closer.

What I saw reminded me of when I'd spend hours at a time playing one of my favorite games of all time, Final Fantasy Tactics. Most Tactical RPG's do that to me, as their style is so distinct in comparison to other genres. The grid on the floor is a dead give away to any one remotely familiar with the genre. Armed with some nostalgic goggles, I dove deeper in to the game Wakfu.

Wakfu is a mix of Tactical RPG combat, with MMORPG sprinkles to top things off while you're not in battle. You'll find your usual culprits; Proffessions split into gathering and crafting, Taxi locations for fast travel, an Auction House in the form of a market"
date: and Mounts and Costumes to show off how cool you are
recommended: just to name a few of the things you'll recognize from the MMO genre. Most of the activities within the game are easily recognized standards that even people who have only played something like Minecraft should be able to pick up quickly. It also tries to do it's own things
hoursPlayed: like a completely player run government
voteText: and an eco system than can give bonuses if its in a good shape.\n\nThe battle system is also pretty standard as far as Tactical RPG's go. Veterans will be able to pick up the battle system quickly
helpfulPercent: as soon as they understand the some times confusing tool tips for their spells. Combat takes place on a field created when you start the fight with monsters in the world. Each participant is put in order based off their "Initiative" stat. The batle then goes by in turns. Each combatant is restricted by how many tiles on the grid they can move
votesHelpful: how far their spells can hit
votesTotal: and how much those spells cost. Of course this sounds simple
votesFunny: but like any great Tactical RPG
commentsCount: there is a lot of depth in this simplistic system

reviewText:
Overall Review/TL;DR (7.5)
Overall I give this game (as of 8/5/2014) a 7.5/10. I'm primarily more in to the FPS and MOBA genres, but the visuals of this game were enough for me to give it a try. To start, the art-style is beautiful, the soundtrack is pleasant and gives the game a nice ambiance, and the animations are amazing! The gameplay (from what I've played so far, which is the tutorial) feels a bit slow, and I feel like the tutorial was unnecessarily long (although I believe you can skip it to begin playing the game), and the controls took a bit for me to get used to, but other than that I feel like this is definitely one of the better MMO's you can find on Steam (not to mention it's free!). I'd say download it, try it, and see if you enjoy it.



Full Review
This is the first MMO I've played in a long time, and it's probably one of the first turn-based strategy games I've been able to play for more than an hour. My opinion is more focused from the average FPS/MOBA player's point of views, please keep that in consideration while reading my review.

Visuals (9)
The only reason I decided to try this game when I got a hold of a closed beta key was the visuals of the game, and once I entered the game they really, really impacted my overall thoughts on the game. The game is beautiful, and the art style is perfect. Not to mention the game's animations are amazing, they truly and firmly say what needs to be said"... if that makes sense. Not to mention character customization is great and makes you really feel unique. The only reason I didn't rate the game's visuals 10/10 was because majority of the playable characters all seem fairly feminine and cuddly

reviewText:
This is the best MMORPG I have played in a while, despite the buggy state it more often than not sits in.

I think what I love the most about this game, is the fact that there's a whole animated series that is based in the same universe as the game, which goes by the same name as the game. They did the same with their last MMORPG, Dofus, which also had an animated series, even though that was more 15 minute short stories instead of a whole storyline of events per season.

All in all, this game is one of THE most unique experiences out there, if you're patient enough to bear with a bug or two every now and then.
I'd recommend it to anyone who is willing to try out something new, as you'll probably never run out of classes to play with the 16 classes already in the game, and the new class coming early December.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Final Fantasy Tactics/Disgaea/2.5D-Turnbased-Game meets French Anime: The MMORPG.
If you're not sold by that phrase, then this game probably isn't for you.

If you are sold, then prepare for a good co-op experience.

That being said, this game mostly shines with its' co-op play. Unfortunately, there seems to be a big void between starting players and end-game players.

If you're starting out in this game, do your best to make links with other people. Make friends, bring friends along, join a guild, anything like that. It'll make the journey from new to end-game all the more pleasant, enjoyable, and certainly easier.

+Wakfu's player side of combat consists of over 15 classes that can straighten down into four roles: Damage, Tank, Support, and Field Control. Albeit, some are a mixture of these.

reviewText:
Did you love Final Fantasy tactics?
Do you love that feeling of accomplishment despite the hellish pain of constant death that rivals even Dark Souls? Do you love deep tactical rewarding strategy based combat?

Then Wakfu will probably be the game for you. On its cute and pristine exterior, there's a huge amount of depth and punishing dungeons and temples. This isn't your average MMO, you wipe in a temple that can take nearly an hour to complete? Well that's too bad, you'll have to start from the very beginning. This isn't some game you can get away with spamming. Positioning, timing and execution is key. Even basic battles against mobs have a strategic depth to them that feels foreign to an MMORPG.

This game runs on turn based grid combat, you level your character like any other in an RPG, however each element has its specialties. Fire is typically AOE (area of effect) , Earth is typically direct damage, Water is usually healing or mobility debuffs or buffs with some damage mixed in. Air is usually knockbacks or line telegraph attacks. But that's only typically, each class feels extremely different. From manipulating time, to picking up your foes and tossing them, to entirely relying on lady luck in combat. Wakfu brings a whole new fresh style to combat that I've never experienced in an MMO before.

Words of warning, if you like questing, you'll find it extremely lacking on quests until you reach the out-lying islands of the nations of the World of Twelve. However they continue to work on updating the game with more quest lines that guide you into areas. I say your first real challenging quest chain is on the Wild Estates, where a mixture of puzzle solving, challenging battles, even sports and an Indiana Jones style hunt for an artifact will take center stage. Did I mention its really hard? Because, it's really bworking hard!

There's a large slew of crafting professions, an entirely player run economy, and the most challenging PVE MMO experience I've ever had. As for the PVP I haven't experienced too much of it. It depends on the server you join but the economy has been somewhat at a standstill and it's more likely you will get trades from your haven bag or face to face than the market. Kamas, the games currency aren't all that hard to get however, especially considering you can mint them yourself.

The game honestly encourages you to find what best suits you, upon recently they updated both the starting area, stat rework making it much more easy to slide into if you're a new player all the while keeping the depth I've mentioned. If you still find yourself in trouble with having a hard time getting started.  Use these newly made video tutorials that Ankama has provided with the steam release, https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaiMvAWwvVTQ_zgPDYP9mozBuwR8VjgwD

All in all, Wakfu is a beautifully designed, deep and well made game that is literally the most challenging experience I've had in an MMO, rivals even what I experienced in my days of EVE in terms depth of combat. There's really a whole slew of possibilities you can approach a battle based on your class and playstyle, those possibilities yet nail biting, hair pulling difficulty is something I do have to admit that I love. We need more games like Wakfu, not MMOs, just games period. This game is the XCOM: Enemy Unknown of MMOs, it's about as tense too. Give the game a shot, add me on Steam if you'd want to party up, don't be afraid to ask questions to the community either, they're quite understanding and helpful, there will be a few bad eggs I'm sure.


In closing, Wakfu is a generously made game, with a lot of love and hardwork put into it, down to the extremely artistic style handcrafted areas, and the lovable design. I would also recommend the first season of the newly released English dubbing of the show. If you tend not to like English dubs, there should be the native French soon enough with English subs. You can also find them online. With a new  third season of the Wakfu anime, a spin off prequel Dofus aux tresors de Kerubim and two movies in the works, a boardgame, and mangas/comics, you can expect more from this game and them on the horizon. So keep an eye out!

reviewText: 2 years ago I would have gladly recommended Wakfu. It had great graphics, fun gameplay and it was sandboxy enough for things to not seem too linear. Unfortunately it kind of spiraled into a huge mess after Ankama rolled out changes that completely split the playerbase. Some people really loved the changes. Others, like me, really hated them.\n\nWhile I personally wouldn't get back into the game in its current state, I wouldn't turn anyone away from checking the game out if only for the novelty. It IS a good-looking game with good-looking mechanics, unfortunately marred by excessive grindiness and a not-so-nice playerbase.

reviewText:
It's kinda rare to see Turn Based Strategy MMORPG.
Wakfu is one of those rare gem. The gameplay kinda similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, but you only control 1 character, well. with sidekicks though, but still not much.

Now on to the review.
+ So many different class to choose of.  Each class have quite a lot of skill, you could make your own unique build.
+ There's a profession system in this game, so apart from the main game itself, you could become a farmer, a blacksmith, tailor, and many more.
+ Community oriented game, you can't sell your stuff to NPC, this game is really community based game, you must actually sell it to people, or... just throw it out. There's Region president election, Guild, and many more. You can join the bad guys, or become a guard instead.
+ For people who prefers playing alone, there's a sidekick system. At least, there's someone to accompany you. Though, i recommend you playing with actual players.


- The community is almost non-existent, many people said this game is still alive, but that's not applied in my case.  I'm playing in asia server, not sure about other server though.
- Grindfest, and it's even worse than other MMO in general in my opinion.
- Customization, There's costume and stuff, but... well, it's not rare to see people with a same face.
- Progression, this game had quite an interesting story, but to progress in the main story is really hard. The level gap to actually progress in this game is really high.

If you have a friend to play with you, i really recommend this game, It's really fun to play wakfu together. If not, find one
right away, join a guild, and have fun.

reviewText:
This game was almost everything I asked for artistically and combat wise and was an extreme upgrade from playing Dofus (which I also loved). I started late; last year and had a beautiful time where I met a very friendly guild, new people, and learned how to do everything up to Present dungeon with the help of many friends.

Although, everything changed when DDOS' were happening where relics were duped and things were magically bought off the market for absurd amount of kamas and everyone became rich. This did not help when the promising new update of Moon Island and Heroes where it basically made everyone play by themselves and did not have to rely on anyone else to do dungeons anymore. Things became very introvert and very independent.

Overall, I would not recommend this game if you start this year and on. The community is very small, but polite (once you get to 175s+) and is very heavy on finding a guild. You will NOT survive alone.

As agreed with many people, this game would have gone a lot further if they listened to the community.

reviewText:
The developper has a shotgun approch to balancing, for 3 months the class I played was unchanged, then suddenly the dev nerf'd dmg output, healing and summons per turn by -50% making it not even remotely viable anymore.

To be clear: that's half the summons and half the damage, so only 25% the original damage potential.

Accoridng to rumors, all because of 1v1 pvp, in a game where pvp is barely even a thing.

Aside from the asinine balance, there is an unbelivable amount of bugs and performance issues. The game is coded in Java and has memory leaks that make the game stutter real bad. A lot of content introduced had been disabled because the dev couldn't figure out how to fix it.

Community seems really young and rude with very few exceptions. There's a lot of white knights" that defend the dev's changes for no good reason and seem to advocate worse conditions for their fellow player. Most likely because they're subscribed and wouldn't be affected by the changes."

reviewText:
I would reccomend this game, but there are certain things about it that different kinds of gamers may or may not like, I'll try to sum up some of the specific qualities.

1: Like most MMOs it's a long grind to the higher levels, but it doesn't feel like you're doing the same thing over and over, generally you get to go through different dungeons and fight new monsters the more you level so you aren't always doing the same thing.

2: You have specific skills you can build, everything from Farming/baking to being a jeweler there's lots of stuff you can do other than punching monsters faces all day, you don't absolutely have to if you're the kind of person who just likes fighting, but it can be helpful and even fun to learn these skills, some sidequests involve using these skills as well.

3: There is a story to the game but it's really not the main focus until you level up drastically, but even so there are plenty of other thing to occupy your time in this game, really half of it feels like you're making your own story with other players, which moves me on to the next topic.

4: Politics, yes I said politics, there is a political and economic system in the game world that is run by the players, you can vote for elections or even become governer yourself, laws are set to keep the economy well (or to leech off of other players if they're a dirty politician) not to mention if you break the law you will be labled at a ciminal that other players will attack, and if you are caught then you will have your character sent to jail, also laws are in place to keep the ecosystem in order, which once again moves me onto the next topic.

5: Ecosystem, yes there's indeed an ecosystem in this game, you want wood? Plant some trees but don't cut too many down, want to hunt some monsters? Make sure too many of them don't get killed but also don't let there be too many ect ect. There are generally laws in place to help keep it balanced.

6: Character Classes, there are a total of fourteen different classes to choose from Damage dealers tanks and healers oh my!" There's tons of variety in terms of how each class plays
date: each have their own mechanics making none of them truly "useless" Yes there's one that's overpowered but even that one has a down side
recommended: so in terms of classes you won't be dissapointed.\n\nSo if the things I just mentioned sound interesting and maybe even fun I would highly reccomend trying this one out
hoursPlayed: it has a beautiful art style and TONS of content to keep you playing!\n"

reviewText:
EDIT
I played this quite a bit since I wrote the review and even got some friends to try it. Thing is, I don't like MMOS. There is something about it that just doesn't work for me.

That being said, this game is an amazing turn based strategy game. If you like MMOs and turn-based combat, do try it!

If you're like me, it's not unlike any MMO. It gets boring too fast.


Original review
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

This game has one of the best turn based combat I've ever played. All playable classes have 20 spells and 5 passives you can skill and level up, allowing you to build it any way you want to suit your tastes. There is a lot of ennemies and they all feel unique.

But that's pretty much it. There is no drive to level up, very few quests beside some for the intro, some milestones and the dailies. That's enough for me but it makes it hard to get friends into the game.

Also, the politics, crafting and environnement things seem like useless or almost useless gimmicks to me.

On top of that, the game have a lot of issues. The Steam achievements are not working (and at this point, I doubt they ever will). When my friend created an account, he got locked into a different region than mine and he gave up on the game.

Give me a propper coop RPG with those classes and ennemies and I would buy it any time.
voteText: 46 of 73 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wakfu is a phenominal game filled with an innovative turn based battle system. Very similar to final fantasy tactics and other games of the genre.

The tutorial is long and tedious because it has to be. The battle system is complex to those new to the genre, but once you can look past that; it's a game that you can tell lots of love and creativity was poured into it.

Classes~ They're so many classes to choose. They vary from the typical archer and warrior to flying faeries and time robots.  Each class has it's own individual spells and abilities. For example, I have an Eniripsa. The Eniripsa is a support/healer class that can spec into fire, air, or water abilities. Without getting too much into this to prevent spoilers, (and because of my ignorance considering I have only played around 20+ hours) I can assure you that each class is innovative and will be fun to play.

People~ People fuel everything in this game. They're no npcs, not too many quests, yet why is this game so fun? Because people make the combat system REALLY ♥♥♥♥ING FUN. You find a party of about 5+ people to do this exceptionally hard dungeon or invade another person's territory ( at level 18 you pick a civilization to live in) and after 25 hours I'm still having so much fun.

Professions- If you want to plant a seed. Plant it ♥♥♥♥ing anywhere. If you want to mine a rock go build a bomb and blow up the rocks to find the rare minerals within. If you wanna go trample on someone else's freshly planted seeds (♥♥♥♥ you btw) then go do that. There's total free roam in this game. ZERO RESTRANTS.

Art style/music~  Wakfu is very colorful. Has pretty good mustic, and a flowing animation. Don't be fooled by it's cartooney style though; this game is ♥♥♥♥ing bloody. If you wanna go kill a cat and cut off it's fur go ahead. The blood will be on the picture in your inventory.


The games completely free~ That's right, it's free. Go play it you nerd.

reviewText: Now I played Wakfu before it came out on Steam, and it was a very fun experience to play through, along with the lore it had and each class having a unique style in their own right. When I got this game and started it up, I was abit skeptical about how it started off. But later in the game I got used to it and I felt right at home. It's a great MMORPG RTS game that I reccommend to those who want to have a fun experience. It's not meant for everyone, but it's something that I will keep coming back to when I feel down. The graphics in the game look pretty nice, and the world is VERY huge aswell. The fights are fun to, having a tile based fight, and each move counts as you try to figure out what to do. And if you have your friends, you can try to come up with more strategy. I was really impressed on the execution, and it's something that I will continue to love until the end of time. Not the best, but it's still unique. I would give this game an 8.67/10

reviewText:
At first, Wakfu is a fun game. It has a really unique gameplay style and fun characters. However, once you get farther into the game, you notice problems that start to pop up. Its starts with small things. Maybe your character bugs out a little, or your spells don't work the way they should, and it isn't too big of a problem to begin with.

But then these things stack up. And up and up and up. The development team is horrifically slow when it comes to fixing issues. Well actually, I take that back. Whenever there is a bug that HELPS players, it gets fixed very very quickly. But if you've got a gamebreaking bug that halves the damage you deal? Well, maybe they will get to it in three or four patches. And you get a patch once every two months if you are lucky. Whats that, your class is broken? Don't worry, you can always buy the 30$ class change!

And don't even get me started on the support, oh lord. I sent in an issue, and a week later, after not hearing anything from them, I tried to contact them again. Again no response. So I tried to contact them a THIRD time, and finally, after almost a month, they contacted me back and said they had looked at the issue, and decided to do nothing about it.

You'll notice I have a lot of hours on this game. That isn't counting the time I put into it BEFORE it was released on steam. Its because they keep promising to fix things. Every patch that comes out I think, hey,  They continue to try and put more and more things into the game without ever fixing the old stuff.  And I hope you like doing hours of research in order to play games! Many stats and spells are ambiguous, and there is NOWHERE in game that explains what they do. So, you have to scour the forums, hoping that your question has been answered somewhere, and that if you do find an answer, it isn't outdated.

TL;DR this is Wasted Potential: The Game". The base concept of the game is great
date: and so much could have been done with it
recommended: but in the end it just leads to bitter disappointment."

reviewText:
I have played Wakfu since the first beta. Since the very start of the game. Since 2011. I thought Ankama Games had the right idea by combining their great game with a great video game company like Valve. Since Ankama Games is a French game company, creating a connection with the United States and other countries really helped the game with one of the problems it had, population of the English servers.

The things that make this game great are the ideas introduced into the game mechanics itself.

The grid-based strategy aspect of the game, combined with the different ways of stat growth and play made this game trully creative with the way players enjoyed the game on a fighting aspect.
Another great form of the game is the creative design of the world of Wakfu. Every city, every character, every monster is unique and beautiful.
One more great feature of the game is the way real people manipulate with the enviornment, the government, and the people who play the game. Wakfu shines with the idea that people have everything and anything to do with the world in which the players play in. The player can manipulate the mobs in given areas. The player can vote for government officals to enact rules for the country to follow.
However, no game is perfect. Wakfu has problems, and unfortunatly the problems happen to be fairly large.

Because Wakfu is a game made from a French company, support is not the best when something happens to happen, whether it be in the game or in real life.
Although the content is large and the world of Wakfu is large, content seems to be lacking for people who don't want to 'level up'. There aren't many different ways to enjoy the game to its fullest, and although Ankama Games has tried to include ways of enjoying the game, it doesn't seem enough to really keep the players they recieve.
I believe Wakfu is a great game and it should be looked at for players who want something different in their MMO. However, Wakfu lacks the ability to keep the players they recieve and although I greatly enjoy the game, and everything it provides, I can't help hoping for more of the game. 6.8/10

reviewText: This has to be my second favorite MMORPG after Ragnarok Online, It IS Free to play.\nWakfu had a Pay to Play restriction in the past, that's gone, now there's full access on anything you wan't to do, the game now has a cash shop where you buy cosmetics, action emotes, furniture for your houses and pets. The community is really nice depending what server you choose, I play on Remington (Europe International Server for English Speakers). The gameplay is a tactical turn based (Example: Final Fantasy Tactics and Fire Emblem) There are about 15 races to be and they all their pros and cons,   all of them are good and bad at the same time depending how what skill tree you decied to level up while in combat. Males are tough looking and Females are cute looking (except for the Enutrofs they are elder characters that love money hehe)...nuff said. I recommend this game if you seek a nice MMORPG. The music is fantastic and its completely 2D, very well animated. Also I forgot to mention, this game makes you farm a lot.

reviewText:
The game itself is amazing, I love every aspect of it (aside from the grinding for professions.) I love the classes, their balance, the combat, the variety of monsters and dungeons. It really makes you use your head.

However, the Ankama support is below zero.
Check the Technical Issues subforum on their website. There are PAYMENT issues regarding Steam that haven't been resolved for nearly a year now. If you are from certain countries (for example, Hungary), you cannot make a payment through their website, because there is no credit card option there. Technically, you could buy stuff via Steam... But in practice, you can't.

If you write to their support and state your problem, they will quickly redirect you to Steam's updated privacy policy, regardless the fact that you mentioned that you've already read it. If you go ahead and do your research, take every measurement to make Steam Wallet work and you still can't buy anything from ingame--the customer service redirects you to Steam, who can't do anything about it, since it's a game-related problem.

This game is good until you don't receive something you paid for/your account is stolen/your account is suddenly wiped. I rarely see a case that got resolved. Read their forums.

If you are a casual player that won't pay for an MMORPG and doesn't want to play it for long... then play Wakfu. Otherwise, I cannot recommend it in its current state.

reviewText:
3/10

It's fun at times and the references can be clever. However, it does not retain my attention for long. It grows rather repetitive and the constant grinding is tedious with little reward until you're well into your 60s-70s level wise(which can, on estimate, can take up to 2 weeks. If you don't care to sleep.).

I, personally, also don't care too much for the grid battle style, which, in no way to me, makes it more difficult, only annoying.

This game bores me and really offers no great difference from any other online MMORPG. For the download time I suffered (I have unreliable internet at times), it really was not worth it in any means.

I have certainly played many MMORPGs, having been playing games since I was eight, and this is certainly not a best". It goes more along the lines of "Those Generic MMORPGS with a relatively simple and boring plot".

Don't get me wrong. The art was great. The strategy involved is wonderful. It is really just the whole "Grindy-grindy until you're whiny. Waste your time and lose your mindy."

I've always been a picky person when it comes to plot and grind. I just can't stand it."

reviewText:
Visuals - This game gives rather colorful and diverse artwork. Every place you go in this game will be different from another place. I'd say the developers spent a lot of time making the open world as beautiful as 2D can possibly get.

Gameplay - As many people will say, this game plays similar to Final Fantasy tactics. You play as one hero in a turn based setting with a series of Action Points to use for spells and a series of Movement Points to walk around. There are large assortments of unique classes and no class plays the same. What makes this game fascinating is how creative every class is.

Players - This game has a surprisingly low population for how fun it is. There are many friendly and unfriendly players like in any Massively Multiplayer Online Game. Since the populations are so low though, some higher level players tend to become localy fameous within the servers.

Story - I have to say, i haven't even touched the story. It seems kinda iffy to begin with. You incarnate into Astrub and do some mercenary work. Than a giant tv face guy tells you that you are the chosen one to defeat the mighty Ogrest. I'd have to say the story for me is the weakest aspect of the game.

A really unique MMO that uses a system akin to that of Final Fantasy Tactics.

However the support for this game is nonexistant and it's not at all player friendly. The world is fun to explore and the combat is just as fun with lots of interesting classes. However due to the lack of support from the dev team and the fact bugs just aren't getting fixed I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
Again and again I find myself returning to this game, only to encounter a diffirent disbalance and same broken AI. One would think that since the game came out, developers could adress these issues. Instead, we get alternative questlines and new cash shop items.

The gameplay is enjoyable. The artstyle is good. But the world feels very, very empty.

The game was originally intended to have a community. Players run faction politics, entire economy and even location ecosystems. It has now gotten to a point where people jump to another server, just because it has a spike in population. Many people who return to the game after a long time seem to be bewildered by the state of affairs.

There is variety of classes, each with their own, unique abilities that grow stronger as you use them. This is great, except because of the aforementioned imbalance, which in turn leads to a class getting nerfed or revamped. Remember that character that you played a while ago that you really liked? Here, have a totally diffirent one.

Crafting is a grindfest. If there was an active economy going, this would have been easier. But if you want to create a good item, you have to personally collect all the components required for a specific item and craft it. Both of these require a good amount of time to get the skills for. And the list of required components can often be quite extensive. This repeated process is the only way to advance in a crafting profession.

There's an extensive list of unique enemies, who often come in matched groups, so as long as you advance in level or just travel a lot, you get to face various new challanges. This only lasts until later levels, when the grind sets in, or when you just need to acquire specific components or a piece of armor. This uniqueness also causes AI to frequently do random things. And woe upon you if you picked a summoner class - healers who prefer full health targets over dying allies, melee summons who decide to just step back a bit and skip turn...

I wish the game would do better, I really do. But so far I've come to be repeatedly dissapointed.

reviewText: Curious, heavily strategic combat system, mounted audiovisual and overall quality will impress many players but...The more you get into it , the more complicated it becomes, after some time appears grind, and micropayments quite clearly show numerously restrictions. It's a shame, thus we miss a lot of joy. Wakfu could be great, and it is just good. Personally, I was not convinced to this position, but maybe because I'm not a fan of this type of game. I found this very good position to be installed on the laptop, because during frequent trips, I can quietly play the levels in Wakfu, instead of playing sapper. On the other hand, you can't fail to notice the enormity of work involved in the production. Drawn graphics, dozens of statistics that describe your character, hundreds of skills, equipment, thousands of quests, in one word good job. Ultimately, this is a niche title that is unlikely to made an international career, but certainly appeals to maniacs of turn-based games and drawn the world.

reviewText:
Hello all! Finny posting here, some of you who are reading this might want a brief review, some of you might just be looking at another Hardcore Wakfu players opinion so I'll give both. Played hours here 600 odd actual? 3.3k (no life)

1st things 1st, this game is extremely unique i've never played a game like this, a game like this is truly amazing and so is the fact that the game is available on the Mac platform (what i'm using).

TLDR: Game is amazing but VERY VERY grind-y, lonely and un-sociable (Read bottom paragraph). Would recommend :]

Story: This is extremely limited, this is newbie friendly but is very short and only links to Ogrest which is still yet to be incorporated into the game (I think this was going to be level 200 content) once you progress to mid 100 content (level 50) the newely revamped islands (currently 2 out of 5-6+) you then get new quest-lines which feature ways to get Kamas (In game money) quicker through even more exploration of the game, this is tedious but can be fun for people who are casual and don't mind spending 20 hours+ running around the game. The story then jutters and jumps to mid game content (level 100, 118, 120 and 125) these questlines again feature kama making methods and are EXTREMELY fun and give an insight into the story of the game and the Ultimate Bosses (weekly bosses, sadly no challenge what-so-ever) you then have the section of the game which is the most grindy, intensive, game quit feeling inducing moment ever, this is the jump from 120 to the next 140 quest, this is the most boring and lonely grind experience ever, this puts most people off the game. From here you have more quests more frequently and you would have probably found a guild and start to have some online Wakfu friends, you then lead into the high level content, I won't speak about this since you'll probably have a basic understanding of the game and some good friends etc.

Guilds: This is all down to preference but the size of the guilds aren't huge and you are basically forced into high level guilds just to see anyone online, there are a few English guilds which are really nice and newbie friendly (notice how I said few, it really is hardly any guilds that are newbie friendly) when entering this game it's not advised to ask high levels for leeching I will give you a quick run down of why:

XP is grindy as HECK
You'll be on 0.5-0.75x XP meaning that someone grinding you a few levels will feel like a life time, period.
Fun factor
Is it fun for high levels? Yes and No, depends on their mood and what you're like as a player etc.
Language Barrier
Hit and miss remember this game is multi-cultural so be wary of whom you ask for help due to language barriers!

In game revenue / money method
This is called 'Kamas' you gain some each fight and with chests that you open from completing a respective Questline, this is tedious but you get quite a lot of money, awesome!
On Remington you have quite a nice economy meaning that while some items are crazy high they are endgame and so you'll only aim for these once you have complete knowledge of the game and dungeons etc. Majority of other high level stuff is dirt cheap so that's cool!

Dungeons:
Fun and grindy you don't have to run it 1,000 time for an item to have 1 chance of dropping it but instead....! You can run it 1,000 times to get enough tokens to buy it huzzzah! So it's all down to your opinion, there's also major awesome guides online showing you how to complete these dungeons as-well as other players that you'll be running with experience!

PvP:
Completely broken due to only a select amount of classes being revamped and overly powerful, unless you follow the crowd with new classes i'd advise against it.

Classes:
Old ones are much weaker and often not taken/ accepted as much in dungeons compared to newer classes, same with other games but sad really R.I.P Sadida ;w;

Bugs:
This game has a fair amount of bugs in it but these seem to be ironed out fairly quickly, until recently where dupers have been duping end game items and selling them for very low prices, this has in turn kinda ruined the economy and the player base due to not trusting the market and other players, a lot of people such as my self feel slightly cheated that new people pick it 1-4 of these duped 20million each relics and I spent months farming 1 worth 4 million... This is a major problem as of May 26th 2015 so if you're reading the review take this into account!

reviewText: Wakfu is a great game, Dofus is its predacessor but it doesn't hold up as much to me. Wakfu has no NPCs to sell items to, and the economy is completely player driven. You can effect the ecosystem, mob spawn rates, have your own guild territory, do HC boss battles that have phases and more. Some are turned off by turn-basec combat, but its really fun once you get used to doing combos, positioning, reading enemy telegraphs, and simply playing in a competent way with good friends. Do yourself a favor and try the game. I play on the Asian server, and the community there is FANTASTIC. Everyone is rather nice, the GMs do contests, and its just a blast. If you don't mind mob-farming a bit, and actual farming, try it out...its free. Nothing to lose. And its not PAY TO WIN. It is completely free. All content, all bosses, ALL EXPANSIONS FREE. The only thing a booster/subscription for the month adds is the ability to vote for a governor for your nation. Thats it. Oh and becoming governor yourself. Otherwise this is probably the best MMO I have played to date now that it free to play and class balances have come to be great.  Do yourself a favor, play Wakfu and enjoy your game time well spent making friends, figuring strategies, and being the best class you can be under your god.

reviewText:
A suprisingly entertaining game that deserves a try by anyone who enjoys turn based strategy games! Obviously similar at first glace to games like Final Fantasy Tactics and the Disgaea series, but with it's own twist and features for online multiplayer!

A few hours in and I still have quite a lot of learn about how to play Wakfu, but that's part of the fun! The medium strength learning curve means things may feel familiar to you from other games, but not entirely.

One of the best designs is the classes themselves. A large number to choose from and not the standard, boring names and designs like Warrior, Mage, and ...well actually there is a Rogue, but it's cool! The artistic design of this game is fantastic and also adds to the familiar, but fresh feeling that Wakfu brings!


Oh, and you get a crate for your bag....house...thing! :D

reviewText:
Great game, fairly addictive.
Addictive how? I don't know how to explain. It's just a personal preference thing.
If you enjoy games that are slow and casual, you'll want to try this out.

You'll spend most of your time harvesting resources you'll probably end up selling.
The combat itself is turn-based, so that's self-explanatory. If you want a fast-paced game, you're looking at the wrong place.
The first 12 levels or so, you'll find yourself with a bunch of interesting quests, but pretty much after that the story kinda disappears. I've only played till lvl 50, but so far I haven't had any storyline quest after the intro.
At any rate, the most appealing factor of this game is probably its style and art. The grind itself isn't hectic, but farming for resources might break your sanity.

Personally, I think this might be more of a social game.
Also, this game has no problem showing animals mating.

reviewText:
I would not reccomend this game to anybody.
I have bin playing this game for a long time from the official site.

Positive:

- Nice art
- Fun turn based combat
- Strategic
- Big world, lots to do.
- Lots of classes, with lots of ways to build them

Negative:
- Cant be played alone (Unless creating multiple  accounts known as multi-boxing)
- Hard to learn. Almost no tutorial to get u anywhere. They drop u in the game and good wish u good luck.
- Grindfest, Dungeons take long and the items have rediculous low drop rates. (Any good item will usually only have 0.1% to 0.3% drop chance. (token machines allow items to be bought with tokens earned from the dungeon, but will still take about 30 runs for 1 decent item)
- Even tho the game is technically free to play. It asks money for tons of things. even certain areas require monthly payment to be accesed (newest areas)
- Bad customer support. Sending in a ticket with a problem can take up to weeks for it to be replied. sometimes it will not even get answerd at all.
- Extremely buggy. The game is FILLED with bugs. And not small ones ether. Things such as duplicating items turn up very frequantly allowing people who abuse the bug to make tons of money without any punishment. Every patch they introduce multiple new bugs. Some so major u wont be able to play for a long time.

(For example as of writing this review they added the 1.43 patch, Witch makes every fight in dungeons bug out. Not start. and force u to relog. On top of that they have serieus lag issues aswell. making it impossible for people to play due to things such as 1 spell taking 10 - 20 seconds to respond. This current bug has bin going on for 3 weeks and still they do not have a clue how to fix it. And even tho they will fix it eventually. With the next patch added 100's of new bugs will come with it aswell. only to remain not fixed for weeks again)

All in all i actually really love this game. And if it wasnt for the horrible costumer support and frequant bugs i would mostly reccomend it.
But i cant. Seeing as u will most likely not even get anywhere in the game, due to bad early tutorials. And constant bugs.

reviewText:
I loved Final Fantasy Tactics A2 and the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon series and always wished for a multiplayer version of those games. This game does a pretty good job of putting the combat experiences of those games in a multiplayer setting.

Besides the combat, I also enjoyed the game's environmental mechanics because it kind of gives me a Harvest Moon or Animal Crossing kind of vibe where the world gives you these resources to do things with, and the players are responsible for tending to them or making something out of them.

As for the grinding, I personally don't know if it is actually necessary or not, but in any case I managed to skip the first story quests altogether and head to my chosen nation (Bonta) and then proceeded to grind the highest level mobs and dungeons that I could manage, purely because I love overwhelming myself in these tactics games and barely pulling through.

It also helps that the only punishment for death is no exp gain for a lost battle, reduced stats for about 3 minutes and a respawn back to the previous checkpoint area of your choosing.

I've spent no money on the game so far, but I might in the future if I keep playing. Paying players get some nice bonuses, but I've been playing comfortably without them. There's also some nifty costumes and stuff too.

I recommend the game because it's free and I enjoy it.
If you get it, I'd definitely recommend doing the tutorial and trying out a few different classes. I went through a couple classes and then went with the Elitrope as my main because I personally loved the portal mechanic. My brother went with the archer because he loved the obscene range and then the huppermage because of the elemental/light attack dynamic. There's a lot of variety, so don't be afraid to try a few out. Also, your lower level alts will gain an experience multiplier to make grinding levels faster,

reviewText: I have been playing this game off and on (mostly on) since 2012. I more than likely have thousands of hours of gameplay which I think is more than enough to warrant me to review it. And yet... reviewing this is hard. The game itself conceptually and artistically is fantastic. It is such a visually pleasing game and the music is pretty great too (after a while I put the music on mute however). You can really feel the thousands of hours of hand drawn work that went into making Wakfu such an attractive game. But the two caveats here is that the game is buggy and the customer support is lackluster at best. But before you turn away and never touch this game - just give it a shot. The game itself is good enough and challenging enough that you might really take to it. If you loved those JRPGs with the word 'tactics' thrown onto the end (or front like 'tactics ogre') of their titles then you might really fall for this game. What is more is that it is an MMO and as anyone who has really dug deep into an mmo knows you start to form bonds with these people that you play with. It is really unlike any experience a video game can provide.

reviewText:
short version:
think final fantasy tactics mixed with a bit of harvest moon (or....augh....farmville.....we dont have long wait times though) and a dash of borderlands comedy into a sandbox MMORPG.

long version:
1.its a turn based MMORPG (all capitals btw,because they REALLY focus on that),there is a good community,and a ♥♥♥♥ ton of classes to choose from,and they're pretty non tradisional,except some ofc.

2.while not as hard as fire emblem,you might need to think of a plan sometimes,like if placing a trap on the floor to finish off an enemy while reseulting to friendly fire (did i mention friendly fire is on?yeah,have fun trolling),

3.No friends or no one to join to help you fight?No problem,they have a sidekick system (although i prefer to call them minions)basicly they're like those characters in turn based RPGs that you can control,they start at level 1 when you get them,so dont be surprised if they have less health,although some have skills unique to them,which can be advantage,you mostly need to get to the cash shop for them,which i hate doing,it is pretty nice of them to give you a free minion (cant help calling them that) after a quest and a trial one every now and then

4.there is a ecosystem....system built into the game,you can replant and harvest some crops/trees and animals(?),if the ecosystem reaches a certain threshold,you get a bonus.

5.professions,there are alot of professions you can chose,mind you professions are different from classes,classes are MOSTLY combat base,while profession is can become a side income or help you in combat by either making food for buffs,close range weapons,AoE weapons (yes there are AoE weapons) or armor,or just a plain hobby,and these professions arent limited to crafting weapons,food or armor,they can also become a handyman or lumberjack or hell,a fisherman,most professions can help each other,so having other poeple in different professions help.

and all those stuff you can get into in a matter of hours,hell i havent joined a guild or faction/nation

pros and cons

pros:
1.free to play
2.an ACTUAL turn based MMORPG thats good
3.ecosystem
4.professions
5.nation (joining certain nations will make you their enemies,which is a nice lore effect)
6.active community
7.secrets within the game,like a portal giving you a cape somewhere in the beginner area (hint:its at the lower right corner of the map,also when you get it,read the description)

cons:
1.with everyone F2P...there are always microtransactions....although its not as bad as others,its still there,they do give you a free sidekick and a mount via quests and 5 character slots....im looking at you realm of the mad god

2.its a birds eye view game,and when you start at the beginner town,its pretty hard to get a grasp of whats what and whos who,like if this chocobo thing does anything or this statue have any fuctional purpose,or maybe if this board will lead me to the market

3.speaking of grasping,they dont really teach you what is what and where,hell i had a friend tell me the minimap pops out via shift+m,and best thing is they dont tell you how to use the market or what it looks like

4.since you have a ecosystem to run,you need to watch what you kill and what you harvest,make sure to replant EVERYTHING you kill just to be safe

5.you REALLY need to read stuff,like badly,if you dont,you might not learn what to do or get the humor of it,its not as bad as dark souls lore being hidden in item descriptions though

6.when you finish the tutorial,you're probably gonna exited to chose your class,the thing what i hate about choosing classes IN GAME (you can probably wiki them for better description) is they're vague,you might THINK that feca's shield is a tank but nope,its a (ranged) buffer and trapper

overall it takes a little learning and adjusting to the game,and if you can do that,you'll start having fun,plus it is a free to play game with optional cash shop

my review:
8/10
give it a go
takes a few hours of adjusting to the game tho
also read item descriptions,you wont regret it
