voteText: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
* Caveats
First of all, the caveats.  If you can't handle these, don't bother:

** Partial pay-to-win
Bonus XP and loot abound alongside otherwise-unatainable items for those who open their wallet.  I wouldn't call it a true pay-to-play since it's entirely possible to compete with people who pay, but it will take significantly more effort on your end.  The items may even make sense in some cases if they're cheap enough, but I would never recommend to anyone the booster pack or paying continuous fees for the new hero system  It's preposterous unless you have far too much money and nothing better to do with it.

** Slow
Tactical, turn-based combat that gives everyone 30 seconds to make their move.  With up to twelve players per battle (6 players per team PvP), there can be something of a wait until your turn.  For me, this is an advantage since I can plan out my approach more carefully, or even do other things while playing (the game makes a distinct sound when it's your turn), but people who prefer action will find it a bit troublesome.

** Confused
Wakfu sometimes wants to straddle the line between single player and MMO.  The scenes when following the main questline definitely try to feel like you're playing through a single player RPG, and those other players with you are all extras.  You, yes, you are the hero of prophecy, and it is your task alone to defeat Ogrest.  It's a neat approach, but the disconnect is sometimes a bit much.

** Trolls
Don't like being randomly killed by someome three times your level?  Might not be your game.  The only way to completely opt out of PvP is to stay in Astrub, where you'll never be able to level far.  Honestly, this doesn't happen often.  Once every couple months or so, it seems to happen to me.  The consequences of losing are pretty miniscule -- You reappear at your phoenix and there's a negative status effect attached to you for three minutes.  My suggestion is generally to ignore them because of this, but some people have strong emotional reactions to this, so they should be aware.

** Performance
My laptop is hardly top of the line, but it plays a number of my games with no problem.  It doesn't even slow down much on Minecraft most of the time, and we know how badly that was coded.  Why, then, does this 2d game sometimes completely tank in framerate even when the graphics settings are at the minimum?  Why can it then run quite well sometimes with the graphics set to max?  There's a wide variation possible based on what's happening at the time, both visually (there was a problem with the steam/smoke effect a few months ago that brought both machines I used Intel cards on to their knees, while my significantly older Radeon didn't suffer at all) and in terms of action (beginning and ending battles, loading areas, players suddenly logging in, etc. can sometimes leave Wakfu unresponsive for seconds on my laptop), so if your machine is fairly weak, prepare for occasional input or display lag.

** Documentation
My goodness.  There are tutorial panels that come up occasionally to try to tech you what's going on.  Some of them are massively outdated, some aren't descriptive enough to be much help, some come up at bad times and block your view, or even mouse (Though most can be dismissed with a click, I encountered one that could not.), at awkward times.  Frequently, the best option is to ask someone.

* The rest
Now, on to the good stuff:

** Class selection
There are a variety of classes that can represent a significant range in play styles.  The classes I love the most aren't neccessarily liked by my friends as I do not always like theirs, which I generally take to be a good thing on variety.  Even within classes, there are a surprising number of variants available based on the spells you choose to bring to battle and where you spent your points when leveling.  There are some respec opportunities available for free (as well as one for cash and one that requires you to collect a rather shocking amount of items), and it's relatively easy to level a character once you learn where to go and what to kill (so you can even discard a character and redo it all if you don't feel it's worth earning a respec).

** Fun combat system
It's not the best system I've ever seen (Makai Kingdom forever, man!), but the combat system is remarkably nice.  With the recent update, you are limited in the number of spells/abilities you can bring to battle.  This has significantly hampered one of my characters, who was a staunch generalist, but it has helped refine a few others.  The spells, active abilities, passive abilities, and attributes of your character are genuinely brought to life by a combat system that effectively allows you to translate your choices during character growth into sometimes novel and interesting results in combat.  It then goes further by offering additional challenges in combat that you can complete for bonus XP and items.  If you decide to go along with it, these can sometimes make a battle much more interesting.  Even enemies notably weaker than you can get complicated when you refuse to give up on any of the challenges, which can be a delightful way to keep things interesting when you need to gather items dropped by weak enemies.

** Graphics
The anime-style graphics are generally well done, with good customization for your character's appearance (Your equipment appears on your character, allowing for great flexibility in appearance if you're not too worried about having great equipment, or you can use costumes to hide it and choose freely.) and relatively fluid animation that feels quite right when put together.

** Story
The story itself is pretty generic, but it's realized in a remarkably nice universe with solid backstory and a wide varity of interesting characters.  Suffice it to say the world has a great feel to it.

** Community
Yeah, I mentioned trolls earlier.  They definitely exist, and there's no real way to control or contain them implemented.  They're a small portion of the population, though.  Some of the conversations and interactions between players are hilarious or intriguing, there's a wide variety of emotes to unlock, and even text smilies are brought to life with the vizage  of your character doing the expression above your head.  There's plenty of people to talk with, and sometimes random people just feel like inviting you to join their group.  Being an introvert myself, I was rather cautious at first, but I've grown rather fond of people randomly inviting me to go stomp through a dungeon or two with them, or to do a bit of this or that quest line with them.  It's really rather fun.

** Types
A bit of a note, the options available to players are a bit more vaired and detailed then Healer, Tank, DPS.  Obviously, there will be damage specialists sometimes, but they can specialize on distance or close combat if they can afford to sacrifice the other, there will also be those who specialize on moving allies or enemies to different spaces in the field to maximize the advantage for their side, characters who can use a great number of status effects on friend and foe alike, characters that place blockages on the field to keep enemies where you want them or who scatter automated turrets or summoned allies across the field to win with sheer numbers...  If you're expecting battle to always be straightforward, you're in for a surprise.

* Conclusion
While I hate some of the free-to-play nonsense, and I mourn the great potential the hero system had before it became the rent-a-slot deal it is, I have a great deal of respect for the effort and thought that has shaped this game into the remarkable thing it currently is.  I enjoy Wakfu a lot, and many of my fellow fans of tactical turn-based combat will likely come to the same conclusion should they give it a long enough try.  I wholeheartedly recommend Wakfu to those who enjoy a good turn-based tactical fight.

reviewText:
This game is a fantastic amount of fun, even compared to many other tripple-A titles. It has a way of easing you into the gameplay and system that fealt like the right ammount of hand-holding and freedom to make mistakes. I do understand that Wakfu or it's parent game Dofus are not for everyone. It being on the turn based and tactical side of MMO's it does take the right fit for a gamer to enjoy.

That being said however if you are new to turn based tactical RPG's and want to give them a try, this game will not let you down. It can work as an excellent introduction into the genre, and the community in this game has proven time and time again to be very welcoming to newcomers, and you will get every bit of assistance you could ask for.

All things being equal, I would highly recommend this game to everyone who enjoys this genre of game and my personal overall score of this game would be around 8.5/10

The flaws are few and not wanting to repeat what my fellow reviewers have said I will make a refrence a particular reviewer for his/her hard work and broad grasp of the game. Having read through the majority of the reviews the one I do most agree with is Myrtæth's.

Myrtæth gives a fairly informative and detailed review of the game. Look her review and should give you every thing else you would want to know.

reviewText:
So.. I played this game before as well as it's predecessor, Dofus. However, I never got into it because it didn't had a F2P-friendly environment due to heavy limitations and restrictions which greatly reduced overall fun and in my opinion doesn't give new players a good impression of the game before even considering spending money on it. Anyway, with the full release on Steam this game seems a lot more appealing as all of those restrictions have been removed. You're truly 'free' now.

As far as I can tell, there's been quite a lot of changes, most of them for the better.. But I'll go ahead and say this game does require you to invest quite some time into it to get somewhere (besides the usual RPG nature) especially if you're totally new to the Dofus/Wakfu Universe. The new tutorial for instance feels odd.. to say the least. You really have to explore and pay attention to what is asked of you, and even then it is sometimes unclear as the general pacing of it is a bit off. I guess in a way that is sort of the tutorial; to pay close attention to what is said and asked. Because after the tutorial you get plunged into a world where you could basically kill yourself if you approach it the wrong way.

Other than that, the game does look promising. The turn-based combat is really fun and a nice change of pace if you're used to the real-time combat from most other games nowadays. Along with the 15 different and unique classes it can be said that there's a great amount of strategy/tactics to be had for grouping up with others and the big battles later on in the game. ..and that's not even the main appeal of this game to be honest. The best thing about this game is that the world is pretty much completely run by the players/community. Politics and total control of the Ecosystem that can and will affect everyone else. Create, Destroy, Rebuild.. you decide.

In short.. upon closer examination and from what I've seen so far, it's a unique and interesting concept and I'm looking forward to exploring it much further. But most of all.. if the concept itself isn't appealing enough, it's 'Free to Play' and aside from a small boost to your in-game earnings doesn't incentivizes a P2W environment as everything else is purely cosmetic.

reviewText:
Wakfu is a tactical MMORPG unlike any other MMO except for its prequel, Dofus.  It has play style similar to Final Fantasy Tactics where combat takes place in a grid.

The character classes (15 of them) in Wakfu (and Dofus) have unique play styles and the classes themselves can be played many different ways.

The spells have a variety of rules, and positioning makes a big factor in damage dealt/recieved.

The art in this game is very charming.  It's very pleasing to just look at the content in the game.

The music is very pleasing as well.  All from playful, cheery music to serious, blood-pumping music.

There is a lot of humor in this game and a lot of funny parodies.  A lot of naughty references are in the game too, but are subtle enough that kids wouldn't (or shouldn't) understand.

Of course, playing in a team with others is a lot of fun (and often necessary for tackling dungeons of your lvl).  Being in a guild & the in-game group finder tool helps with playing with others to enjoy the game better.

Players can also make an impact on the environment.  Most mobs can be planted to have them spawn, and they can also be killed enough to have very little to no population in the area (sometimes ghost forms appear when that happens). Flowers, Trees, and crops can also be planted in the world and are shared with others, and they can also be completely harvested with none left for others.  Making certain plant/mob population too high or too low or just right can affect area bonuses and nation bonuses.  One nation (Riktus) benefits from other nations having their bonuses ruined.

The environment, plus nation laws and wars set by a governor voted by its citizens (who then can appoint other people to different positions in government), makes for interesting experiences in the world.

I've been playing this game for a long time (since open beta Jan 2012).  It's enjoyable and I recommend it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
PROS:
Best ever game environment.  Beautiful art and style. Extensive crafting system. PVP option. Dungeons are unique and mob's are difficult to master-  they all have different abilities. Gameplay grind and difficulty creates a relatively mature player base. Can play for free if you can stand the grind punishment.

CONS:
Gear acquisition until you have a maxed out character is very punishing! If you're used to Warcraft dungeons, where you can get all the gear you need that matches your level running  dungeons, you're going to be frustrated. Dungeons AT YOUR LEVEL, are DIFFICULT for a group, YOUR LEVEL. So you're basically left with hoping you have some maxed level freinds to run you through, over and over. Which by that time, you've leveled past the gear you were after in the first place. The system really makes no sense.

Getting groups at levels other than high levels is hard. Most players are maxed and have no incentive to help you with low level dungeons. They need to introduce player scaling and rewards so high level players are compelled to play low level dungeons.

BIGGEST CON:  THE GRIND.
It's the most punishing grind I've ever experienced- even if you purchase booster packs for 3x the XP. Now I only get to play an hour or two here and there and on weekends, but I've been playing about a year and my highest toon is 115 out of 165. People get around this by being power leveled" by high level players- which is about as fun as teasing a cat with string... You're just there for idle chit chat while they blow mobs down- for hours....

SUMMARY:
One of my favorite games ever due to art
recommended: playstyle and difficulty. But it has serious flaws with helping and keeping new players interested (grind and grouping).\n\nBest summarized as an MMO Chess Game."
hoursPlayed: January 17, 2015

reviewText:
I really want to like this game.  I mean I REALLY want to like it.  There are a few things preventing me from giving my full life to this game.

-Pros-

-Great design and look

-Unique classes

-Interesting skills (more on this later)

-If you like tactical RPGs and MMOs then this is probably for you.


-Cons-

-VERY complicated for a beginner to get into. (this seems to be a theme)

-Not very beginner friendly, most things have to be explained by long-time players within the game.

-Skills are horribly explained, skill buffs/beduffs are explained in pop-ups within pop-ups within pop-ups at times.

-Very convoluted texts and quests.

-Some things such as haven bags, setting a location, and professions aren't explained very well at all.

-Unexplained reasoning for actions having to be taken by the player, such as HAVING to have a respec at lvl 10 or you cannot fight anything in the game, ever.  If this is a bug of some kind, it should be stated as such by the developer.  Otherwise, it's quite jarring to suddenly realize you can no longer battle anything in the game.


Again, this game is great and has wonderful depth to the classes and skill sets, but the convoluted execution of it all does not create a well-thoughtout package for beginners.  The tutorial in the beginning leaves much to be desired and only prepares the player for the battles.  Everything else in the game has to be found out, missed, or learned through other longtime players in the game.

I still recommend trying this game out and see if you are willing to spend the time necessary to learn all of what it has to offer.  I'm still learning as I go, gaining a little bit more knowledge as time goes on through other players.  It's a slow going process but it might pay off in the depth and fun to be had.

reviewText:
I have over 100 hours sunk into this game so I feel that I can properly review this game, if you do not want to read the whole review then scroll to the bottom to see the pro's and con's, here we go.

Wakfu Is a turn based strategy anime MMO RPG (a mouth full I know) by Ankama. This game originated from France, something pretty rare to come from them, it also has a anime that is subbed and dubbed in English on Netflix. The gameplay is something new and unique to this style of game, it takes concentration and planing in battle, should you use up all the points to move in close and unleash a flurry of attack or stay back and chip away at you enemy is up to you and your class. This system makes PvP a real challenge, most classes can far well in PvP due to the way you can build your class, all classes have at least some ranged spells, even those up close types.

Oh boy the classes, one of the best things about this game next to the combat. There are 17 unique classes that all have there own style of play, some examples are the Cra, your run of the mill pew pew archers, they have accses to these things called beacons, which they can use 3 different elementle attacks on the beacon which will have different affects depending on the element (Air, Fire, Earth). Another good example is the Sram, this class is all about assassination, going invisable and closing the gap behind there prey, also they use giant scythes, whats not to love.

The community of this game is hit and miss, you will have some people that are nice and try to help you and some who spam you with guild invites because they just want more guild points. The big areas where people gather are hot spots for spam bots trying to get you to go buy accounts and that junk, just put those people on your ignore list, the starting area seems to have some pretty chill people but if you are new or do not like trash talkers DO NOT go to The Temple of Scriptures. The Temple mostly has high level people that challenge eachother to PvP at the base of the steps, after sitting there for an hour to listen in on people all they do is call eachother homophobic slurs and offensive names, unfortunately you will have to come here once a day for a quest and it is also the best place to do high level gear trading due to all the high level people hanging around there.

Are you one of those save the earth" people? Well guess what
date: this game has its own eco-system that you
hoursPlayed: have control over. Do you wanna make a jungle? Go right ahead. Wanna destroy another nations resorces and laugh as they can't craft anything? Well you can

flood your lands with rain.

-------------------------------------------------

In the end

reviewText:
Wakfu is a tactical turn based rpg successor of the Ankama game named Dofus. The world is the same in both games, but the time and story have a huge leap, while you have almost all the same classes, the skills each one have is different in every one of them. But not different in sense that is only an upgrade, it's more about a different system without touching the gameplay itself, which is quite frankly almost the same.

Like j-rpgs and korean rpgs, wakfu is a game where you gonna need to grind a lot in order to get strong, craft, obtain powerful gears. that could bother some players that wish to have more action. well in that case this game is not for you. Also it's a teamwork game, so party, groups, friends, guild is a must. Of course you can play solo, but you will need multiple accounts to fulfil your party.

The wakfu art is very cartoony and charming, I really enjoy the draws since Dofus, the french guys really got nice artists. Heck they even did an animation with tons of episodes , it's interesting , cool and a great addition to the game story and vision on the world of the twelve.

Unlike dofus in wakfu you don't have to be a subscriber in order to play, But obviously if u p2p you have advantages suck as + 30% exp and drop bonuses. Howeever the game isn't p2w so no worries about that, every player can have the same stuff that someone that paid have. Most of stuff are cosmetics or consumables.

Altought is not all rainbows and sunshines, the game currently have a few bugs that has to be fixed. The devs are kind enought to give a compensation, but some stuff may still bother some players. Keep that in mind if you gonna play.

See you in the world of the twelve ^^

reviewText:
Wakfu is a turn based mmorpg with a cute anime-like style. The combat system is similar to final fantasy tactics and players are able to shape the the environment. But there are not a lot of quests that will tell you what to do and lead you the way, it's more of a sandbox game where you decide what to do and where to go.
If you prefer quests from Lv. 1 to XXX this game will not appeal to you.

Main Quests:
When you create your character you will get your first quest chain until like Lv. 12-15.
I think the next is around Lv. 35 to get your first mount.
The next one is at Lv. 50
Then there is another one around 90~100
...

As you can see, there is alot of spare time between those main quests. So, if you don't like to explore the world yourself, you will be stuck after each quest chain ends.

Classes and Spells
There are 16 classes to choose from, each once has its unique fighting style. These are no archetype classes you'd normally expect. Except like 3 classes which are similar to Warrior, Archer and Assassin. But you probably won't know which one is the warrior, if you see them, they are more like a mix of a Barbarian, a Warrior and an idiot (The game calls them stupid, not me I swear). There are also Faries, Bamboo-Milkoholics, Machosists, Robots, Human-Plants, Gambling Cats, old greedy Farts, Terrorists and a few more...
But there is no higher class change at a higher level or something like that. You will be stronger when you level up your Class abilities and elemental spells.

There are 4 Elements: Fire, Water, Earth, Air. All Spells in the game are categorized in one of them.
Each class has access to 3 Elements, 5 spells for each Element.
Each class also has 10 Class specific supportive abilities. 5 of them are active spells, the other 5 are passives.

What are the elements for? Everything has Elemental Damage and Resistance.
If you have a lot of Fire Damage, your fire spells will deal more damage, if the target you attack has a lot of fire resistance, you will deal less damage with your fire spells.

Elemental damages can go over 100% to infinite. Elemental resistance has a maximum of 100%(which would block 100% damage of that element), but you cannot reach that. I have about 60% resistance at Lv. 105. So you can at least reach that :)
For your first 20% resist in each element you will need 100 points in resist, which are 5 points for each % resist.
After that it will slightly increase the amount needed for each % resist.

Leveling
The best way to level up your character is probably by doing dungeon runs. You get a wisdom bonus in there, which increases exp gained. 20 Wisdom = 20% more exp after the fight. To enter a dungeon, you will need the corresponding key, which are usually not too hard to get. If you know what monsters are inside the dungeon, kill the same monsters outside of the dungeon, they will drop it sooner or later. You can also craft keys by using the items those monsters drop. Usually its 7x Item X.
There are also daily quests in each zone of the world, which tells you bring 10 items of the monsters that are lurking around. If you collect 20, you don't need to hunt them tomorrow, just accept and finish the quest immediately. Those quests give you a decent amount of exp.
I think in all zones except the first one in each nation are also timed events with a small variety of quests. There are either monsters appearing, or other random stuff you have to interact with before the time runs out. Those are highlighted in green if you see them while the event is ongoing. There is a new event every 10-15 minutes I think and the exp is also decent if it's around your level.


There is a lot more to talk about this game but if I tried to explain every detail I know, I would need 2+ hours to write this review. I will try to end this with a short Pro and Con.

PROS

+ High Variety of Classes (16 Classes)
+ 10+1 Crafting Professions (the extra profession can't be leveled. you can create in game money called Kama with it, if you have the materials)
+ 6 Gathering Professions
+ Battles get more challenging at later levels (monsters gain passives, you can't always ignore to win battles)
+ You have your own home, which is a bag and is accesible from almost everywhere (You can put furnite in it, plant stuff and there is an item storage)
+ A lot of costumes for customization. Also everything you wear, besides the belt, can be seen on your character, haven't seen that in many 2D games.
+ If you don't have friends, you can have 2 Sidekicks fighting by your side.
+ Shape the world, Kill monsters, replant them, cut trees and flowers and plant them where you want em, but be careful, in the open world everyone has access to this.

CONS
- Bugs, Glitches. The longer you play, the more you will find. Some are just minor bugs that don't matter much, others are killing you in battle. The worst battle bug I know is that you can't do anything for 1 round. I have that once in maybe 2 weeks. The friend I play with has it every 25-30 battles. I guess, it depends on your computer.
- lack of guidelines
- Most crafting professions don't feel satisfying to level (only a few things you can craft are better than hunting equip)
- Some gathering professions are really slow and boring to level (Ex.: Trapper, most stuff you collect from monsters to level up will be thrown away to save item slots)


I play and like this game because the combat is fun and challenging to me. In an even battle, every wrong step you take, might cost you or your party members life. The special effects are also pretty well done.
If some bugs and glitches scare you away, you won't be playing for long.
Give it a try if you like most of the things I have mentioned about Wakfu. If the bugs you find don't affect your gameplay experience too much, you will enjoy it.

reviewText:
Alright before anyone complains about my time, I played this during its closed beta period and I have the costume and title to prove that.

Now:

wakfu is pretty interesting for a mmo as it takes turn based strategy to the next level by making you have to think ahead to compete with others.

For Example: I play a xelor, which is one of the least player friendly classes you can play. To use this class properly you have to understand how to use the dial ability that comes with the race/class. Proper use of it will lead to either your victory or imminent downfall.

Now for those of you who are free to play gamers: Fair warning, I'm not sure if this game still uses its membership policy or not for minting kamas and using your factions land. So if it does, you are only really going to be able to affect the eco-system of the starter region, everywhere else you will need membership to modify. If it does not do that anymore than thank god and good riddens. Now go out there and train your skills.

.... And thats all I got for this review...

reviewText: So let's get this out of the way...it is not perfect.  I am not going to preach that it is the best thing since sliced bread but I am not going to say it is absolute ♥♥♥♥.  This game was made with children in mind and some of the visuals and names suggest the same.  This game was also a game you had to pay to play but as you can see it has gone free to play.  However, I do from time to time find some really funny, slightly immature jokes, that actually make me pause and laugh.  The infamous section in one of the regions named Mourning Wood is a big example of this.  There is even references to pop culture such as TMNT and it pokes fun at that series and the series of MMORPG's in general in some points.  However, some references are actually quite infuriating with their difficulty.  This can be solved with grabbing a friend or guild mate and running dungeons.  If that doesn't help you can always take up one of the environment quests that happens every so often that spawns in either special enemies or special objects into the world for a time and if you finish the quest, you get a decent reward of experience so it is not completely pointless.  They make the world feel very alive with the mobs interacting with each other and carrying out their daily routines.  There is also a special form of housing in this game called Havens.  You get a Haven Bag after the tutorial which is your portable house.  You can craft decorations to decorate or sell your useless ♥♥♥♥ to the unfortunate if you have a Display case to store them on.  There are also large zones for your guilds called Haven Worlds which contain buildings and houses.  I do not know much about this due to my guild being only level one.  But you can do Guild Quests which are 3 random assignments assigned every so often to earn guild points to help your guild level.  In addition to these quests, you can fight other guilds and other nations (Nations are basically a form of Alliance vs. Horde style and there are alliances and stuff and blah blah blah.) and earn guild points for every person in attendance of the battle.  Dungeons require keys that you can either farm off of the surrounding mobs, buying them from others or marketplace, or by crafting it if you have the materials and the proper training.  Dungeons are far from a cake walk and most definetly require at least one other person to help you.  But if you don't have anyone to play with, don't worry, you can unlock side kicks which are your companions that you control which come with their own abilities and can help you win the battles.  It plays similar to Final Fantasy Tactics.  As you use them, they grow more and more powerful.  So do your elemental abilities.  Of the probably 16 or so races, all can use magic, just some use it better than others, and there are specific spells just for your race.  You can have ordinary weapons, though these do not scale in damage and efficiency as you use it, so magic is a prefered option for heavy hitting.  Harvesting even has special encounters to mix it up, if you win, you gain 10x the resource you were collecting but if you fail, it halves your productivity with harvesting anything for an hour and it stacks higher and higher until you beat him, when you win, the buff and all the stacks are gone.  Good balancing.  This game is very strategy focused and if you get surrounded with no assistance, you are doomed.  Character customization needs some work but it is still great with some of the choices they give.  Combat is fun, dialog is interesting, and the social aspect is there.  There is no advertisers and everyone is friendly for the most part.  I recommend this game highly to all who love a challenging turn based strategy RPG.

reviewText: Sure, the hours I've put in for Wakfu on Steam so far have been measly, but I've been playing Ankama's games ever since Dofus came out back in 2005. Any avid Wakfu player should know that Dofus is the game that started it all.\n\nBut I digress. Wakfu is definitely worth your time if you love RPGs. If you don't, well, now's the time to start loving them. Beautiful, artistic, modern graphics combined with addicting gameplay, old school turn-based action, and funny NPCs make Wakfu a blast from the past as well as a next-gen RPG. So go ahead, give it a try, and if you don't like it then you can go back to CS:GO and/or TF2 and leave the rest of us alone.

reviewText:
Now that Steam has fixed its issues with Achievements, I'm enjoying seeing what I didn't realise I never knew about Wakfu. I started with Dofus, and gradually made my transition to Steam where I discovered more resources and a larger fanbase of my favourite games.

Wakfu, like its predecessor, is a player-controlled environment where the ecology and economy of the world are entirely dependent on the users. While that seems simple enough, the game goes slightly further, allowing players to be elected as the governing rulers of an entire area of the map, dictating how money should be spent, and how the environment should thrive. The downfall to the above is that 100% of your item profits are from users. There are no NPCs to whom you can sell or trade items from your inventory.

With a large collection of classes, Wakfu (and Dofus) has ensured the general availability of most preferred character archetypes, and has done extensive work keeping all the classes fairly well balanced. The tutorial is only generally comprehensive, so it's strongly suggested that trying a new class is done in the Incarnum world where everything is easy enough to not concern oneself with the dangers of durress. I personally prefer playing support roles, and have found that the highly acclaimed Eniripsa is fun, but the Eca and Xelor make healing very different, and definitely a lot more worthwhile in the aspect of overcoming challenges.

Leveling is tedious, and the quests aren't very well thought out, so once you're finished with Astrub, prepare to grind. The maximum level takes a while to reach, especially since it's primarily done by grinding the entire way after LV20. Max level is 170 at the time of this writing, so there's a bit of perspective. The dungeons are awesome! when you can get friends to tag along, especially if you're following the difficult to locate storyline. I've read the manga and watched the anime, so seeing the dungeons and being part of the story is definitely a great deal of entertainment for me.

If you're having a tough time getting through an area or quest, and haven't made friends on your server yet, no problem; Sidekicks are available in the market for Ogrin. If you're from Dofus, you know Ogrin can be purchased with Kama (in-game money), and thus is possible to acquire at no cost (for those who prefer not to pay). As a long-time subscriber, I highly recommend you give Steam's monthly options a try. I'm used to getting a pet or piece of gear with my Ogrine each month, but Steam goes a step further including more items that are only available through the now gaming giant.

My final, most important factor to playing Wakfu is this: It's adorable! I love cute, and Ankama has done a great job at giving exactly that to me. Have fun, everyone, and feel free to join me on Nox or Remington. Just let me know you're coming.

reviewText:
A very beautiful and unique take on MMOs. The strategic turn based combat is very well done, the monsters, skills and spells look good and its a world I keep going back to. Like any MMO, it will take you some time to level, but the game gives you a companion that makes levelling a lot quicker than it otherwise would be. Im more than happy with the pace of levelling and you get a level every couple minutes if you are in level appropriate areas.

The only thing that frustrates me is that the game has recently been updated to be a lot better and more friendly to players, but the player wikis have not been updated to reflect this. Mob levels have changed, some locations have been moved about, and I have found myself directed to places that no longer have the item i require once or twice. But the exploration aspect is a very big plus.

Overall, an amazing game. Like it so far (180+ hours as I write this) and will udpate if my feelings change

reviewText:
Picked it up in closed beta, got disappointed due to the P2P restrictions that Ankama (finally) lifted for a better microtransaction model. Nothing blatantly overpowered in the cash shop, and all content is finally open.

Very solid game - a bit lacking in direction and story, but if you like your turn-based RPGs you will love Wakfu's combat. There is a large grind, so beware! I also like the dynamic nature of the game world and the fact there is no loot rolling (nodes still are public and contestable, though the game's ecosystem" feature takes care of that most of the time).

Well worth a try for anyone looking for a refreshing MMO or turn-based RPG experience."

reviewText:
Charming aesthetics. Reminds me of a more modern Ragnarok Online and Final Fantasy Tactics. Wide variety of classes to fit multiple playstyles and you get free respecs at levels 30 and 80. Combat is turn-based, so that might not be everyone's cup of tea.

I played this once before two years ago, it was terribly terribly grindy. Now, they've lessened that grind just enough to make it more enjoyable. Leveling crafting is still rather grindy, and good luck finding beanstalks.

Community definitely needs more players, however, and it can be hard to find up-to-date information on something as the game has gone through many changes over time. More players can certainly help this, though, so I'm trying to spread the word!
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is great!

I played this game in the early beta before it went p2p and quit a long time after that. I started playing again when it wend f2p and now I use steam to play it.

The game is much like it's predecessor Dofus. A turn based tactical mmo. But unlike Dofus you can change the world around U in real-time. Kill a lot of monsters and they get extinct cut down a lot of trees and there gone. And you can of course plant trees to let them regrow and you can even plant monsters so they come back.

There is a lot of crafting in this game and you can do them all! I advise you to at-least take up backing and farming because bread is the most used way of healing after a fight. You can wait to heal, and that's OK when you are low lvl. But after a while when you get to a point where you have a lot of HP it will take to long to just wait to heal.

There is a recent revamp of the game that changed the lvling up system. I think it did this in a good way and allows for more unique builds. They also did a revamp on the in game sets. You used to get a bonus from having a X amount of set items. These bonuses are now on the items themselves and the dmg type a set have is now randomly generated. I understand why they did this. So you can have any item you want and not be forced to use a complete set just to get that +1AP. But I Prefer the old system. That update has broken the economy a bit to. Items sell for a lot less now and its a lot harder to earn a decent amount of in game currency (kamas). But I hope that this is just now and will recover in a while.

I think its best to join a active guild because this game really has a nice community. And its best to play with others.
Best thing about the turn based system is that you have time to chat in fights with your team and discuses tactics our just have a good chat.

All in all its a great game and recommend it to everyone to try. It has a nice player-base, looks great, easy to run on almost any machine and although you can go P2P and never feels you have to, F2P gives you just as much to do in the game.

reviewText:
TL;DR- Great Tactics/♥♥♥♥♥♥me. You should give this amazing, under-rated game a shot.

Wakfu is an amazing game that doesn't get enough credit. It has been (mostly) improved by the most resent major update. (9/9/2014) The art and animations in this game are beautiful, the music isn't bad, and the new revamped level up system makes the game much more accessible, and actually give you a feeling of progression over the old stat system. If you like Tactic games and MMOs I don't see how you would not enjoy this game. There are two free and effortless character respecs. The first is given at level 30, when you have all of the skills unlocked and plenty of time to try them all out, and another at 80, when you have a much better understanding of the game. Aside from the two respecs given you can do a quest to respec, or buy a respec from the cash shop, to save time.

There are many classes to choose from, and they are all very different from each other. You have the more basic classes, such as the Iop, who is just a front line warroir. Then you have the much more complex classes like Xelor, whos spells have alternating effects every turn. On top of that each class can be played multiple ways. No matter what class you are looking for Wakfu will have a character for you.

The new starter zone/quests are mostly enjoyable. The starter quests explain a bit more, and reward with more items that you weren't introduced to at all before, such as; Weapons/Armor, Haven Bag Decorations, Shop Stalls. Inventory Bags, and a Pet. HOWEVER. The quests themselves are ... not very fun. Its not that they are bad, or poorly done, but they do not fit into this game. A sliding block puzzle is great, but not in a turn based tactics game. The other quest that doesn't fit uses silly context to teach you the mechanics to a (boss?) fight that you have to do right after... It would have been much more enjoyable to just FIGHT something. There is a daily quest NPC on every map that is simply collect X from Y and bring them to me. Much less annoying. Although nothing original there, if you are fighting the monsters to level anyway, it is a welcome bonus to exp. I have not tried the new Mercenary" quests
date: so I cant give a review on those.\n\nDungeons are fun (I enjoy them at least) and there is no lack of them. The new token system means you wont run a dungeon 20 times and still not get the drop you were looking for. On top of this
recommended: any item from the token machines is account bound
hoursPlayed: so you can't flood the market with items you got from boss tokens. At the start of the game Dungeons and boss fights are simple and straightforward
voteText: the further you get into the game the more challenging and complex dungeons become.\n\nPVP has had more content added in the recent update
helpfulPercent: bringing PVP gear and rewards. Much more active PVP with the nation vs nation
votesHelpful: and limited alliances between nations. If you do not have PVP turned on the only way someone can attack you is through the PK system
votesTotal: witch was already in the game. The level range to attack other players with PVP turned on is much too high right now
votesFunny: at 50 levels apart. I have high hopes that they will lower this range to 20
commentsCount: at the most. I believe for that to happen we would have to see a population increase.\n\nThe Ecosystem ... system
column16: is both fun
column17: and frustrating. On any given map there are values of monsters and resources that should be on the map
column18: within your nations you gain points by putting said resources within these ranges. While the ecosystem is in balance
column19: you will also enjoy a buff on that map. The Riktus clan gains bonuses by destroying this balance
column20: so this also fuels PVP. The frustrating aspect of this is that little to no players seem to care about the ecosystems
column21: the problem with that is that monster populations are a part of these. I have gone to maps with monsters nearly extinct because no one is repopulating them. An easy process through gathering from said monsters
column22: and simply using the gathered material on an empty cell on the map. I believe the reason behind this is no one really want to level the professions used to manage these things. As much as I would love to see a population increase I fear it will bring mass extinctions to the beginning areas of the game

reviewText:
Charming aesthetics. Reminds me of a more modern Ragnarok Online and Final Fantasy Tactics. Wide variety of classes to fit multiple playstyles and you get free respecs at levels 30 and 80. Combat is turn-based, so that might not be everyone's cup of tea.

I played this once before two years ago, it was terribly terribly grindy. Now, they've lessened that grind just enough to make it more enjoyable. Leveling crafting is still rather grindy, and good luck finding beanstalks.

Community definitely needs more players, however, and it can be hard to find up-to-date information on something as the game has gone through many changes over time. More players can certainly help this, though, so I'm trying to spread the word!
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is great!

I played this game in the early beta before it went p2p and quit a long time after that. I started playing again when it wend f2p and now I use steam to play it.

The game is much like it's predecessor Dofus. A turn based tactical mmo. But unlike Dofus you can change the world around U in real-time. Kill a lot of monsters and they get extinct cut down a lot of trees and there gone. And you can of course plant trees to let them regrow and you can even plant monsters so they come back.

There is a lot of crafting in this game and you can do them all! I advise you to at-least take up backing and farming because bread is the most used way of healing after a fight. You can wait to heal, and that's OK when you are low lvl. But after a while when you get to a point where you have a lot of HP it will take to long to just wait to heal.

There is a recent revamp of the game that changed the lvling up system. I think it did this in a good way and allows for more unique builds. They also did a revamp on the in game sets. You used to get a bonus from having a X amount of set items. These bonuses are now on the items themselves and the dmg type a set have is now randomly generated. I understand why they did this. So you can have any item you want and not be forced to use a complete set just to get that +1AP. But I Prefer the old system. That update has broken the economy a bit to. Items sell for a lot less now and its a lot harder to earn a decent amount of in game currency (kamas). But I hope that this is just now and will recover in a while.

I think its best to join a active guild because this game really has a nice community. And its best to play with others.
Best thing about the turn based system is that you have time to chat in fights with your team and discuses tactics our just have a good chat.

All in all its a great game and recommend it to everyone to try. It has a nice player-base, looks great, easy to run on almost any machine and although you can go P2P and never feels you have to, F2P gives you just as much to do in the game.

reviewText: You've already played this game twice. The first time was when the game was still under Squarenix's publication (They later relinquished it due to Ankama's lack of management). You left it once the game left beta and it created one mistake after the next. The second was when everyone flocked to the SEA servers which were free to play, unlike the American one's monthly fee for a laggy java game. You quit a second time after you calculated it would take you months of clicking on rocks to get your mining level to where you want it to be.\n\nNow you want to try it again. Oh, maybe it will be better. Maybe it will be more fun. While you're betting on that, Ankama is betting on you falling into the same trap for the third time. Just go watch the anime if you want your French hips so badly.

reviewText:
To be honest i was a bit sceptical with this game since it was by the same producer that made dofus. I mean i really liked dofus but the pay2play subcription was a real downside. But turns out wakfu is huge improvemen of dofus and best of all it is completely no subscription to be able to enjoy the whole game content.

8/10
I would recommend playing this game if you like turn based combat. Alone or if you have a friend to play with that would be much more fun from low lvl up to high lvl.

Pro:
+ Player driven economy
+ 4 nations with players controlling them/governing them with rules chosen by the leader" of the each nation.
+ Can start war to control more lands for your nation or become allies to control more lands together
+ All class skills are available once you have reached past lvl 10 and they have their one lvl depending on how much you use it in combat
date:
no more lvl up for one skill every 10-20 lvls
+ Turn based strategy combat <- I LOVE STRATEGY <3

Cons:
- No Trade NPC to sell junk item to so you can get easy kamas(games currency).
- Rather hard to find party at low lvl since you get your own sidekick and lvl up rather fast alone.

Currently i'm around lvl 20 so don't have much experience of this game but i have played dofus and reached lvl 40 or so. The similarity are almost identical but with new changes."

This is my experience of finding Wakfu.

I really love a legendary game Final Fantasy, all of them. but the most I personally like, is the tactic. I played it on every game station it has. Started on PSX, then Lion War on PSP came out, I even installed emulator so i can play on my phone. Thats how much i Loved it.

The Grid-Based battle. The Story written. The Plot. The Character classical grinding process. The Class complexity and lots of skills each of them have.  The Game was simply.. perfect.

Until I reach a point where I want to explore another great game with same criteria. I try a lot of games, not very satisfying. Sometime the battle was not good, the story not interesting, too easy. it always lack of something, that tend to makes me stop playing. Maybe  FFT is the best game after all." reviewText: Like it's older brother Dofus, Wakfu is a lot of fun to play, with the advantage of perhaps being even better, and free. Turn based combat is well executed, and the universe of the game is compelling. However, while the idea of an in-game ecosystem to maintain is brilliant, the way it is actually implanted is rather disappointing, it never really feels like your actions have a true impact. Still, it's a solid turn-based RPG, and that's rare enough to be applauded!

reviewText:
Definitely one of, if not THE best MMO I've ever played. Other than amazing graphics, rather catchy soundtrack and a real user-friendly community, the list of faults is pretty small.

Pros- .Flexible combat design. Lots of options to change strategy without losing the feeling of a fast-paced
challenge

.A friendly community that is fairly easy to emmerse yourself in and almost stress-free when looking for guilds to
join which is also encouraged since guilds provide helpful allies and stat bonuses.

.Not the average Pay-To-Play game. Subscribing does give you an upperhand to make you near invincible.

.And the class are extremely even, making the duels come down to skill and smart builds.

.The item crafting system gives an even larger feel to the gameplay, broadening the options further.

Cons: .Like in most online games, it's got the fair share of trolls and ne'er-do-wells. Usually in the form of player killers
or simply disrupting the ecosystem.

.When new to the game, walking around to find dragoturkeys takes up a large portion of your time. The spacing
between each dragoturkey, depending where you are, makes it especially tedious should you forget to
'remember' one. However, this is do-able thanks to lush, vivid scenery and overall whimsy.

.A good amount of loot or quest rewards could be tagged as 'linked', making it impossible to trash. This could be
a mild irritation due to the fact that enough of these items could take up useful inventory space. A good way
to bypass this is to click the trashcan icon manually on each item instead of the click and drag.
Though I found, sometimes, this does not work.

.Your character's journey is NOT narrated by Morgan Freeman.


Other than that, it really is a great game all around. The tutorial is HIGHLY reccomended for people new to class-building
and strategy games. Each Spell, Passive, Stat and combat mechanics can seem a bit overwhelming at first, despite the childish look to it. I say, it's free, try it out.

reviewText:
I am a Foggernaut, distance-classified Stasis robot.
I live inside a bag.
My favorite thing is to mine iron and go on Motherfogger mode.
My Motherfogger mode is extreme. I fire off my Stasis shots all over the place.
It is sticky, I know. But it does the job.
I am from the Brakmar Nation. I'm an Outlaw Gangster because I killed Tufus.
Tufus are no longer overpopulated in Brakmar, but my reputation is still low.
Recently I learnt a close-combat spell that is called Shebang.
Shebang allows me to attack multiple enemies at once.
Unfortunately, I can't cast Shebang during my Motherfogger mode.
There is no way I can leave my nation, even if nobody likes me.
Only my Motherfogger mode and Shebang spell can keep me company.
I am a Foggernaut, a distance-classified Stasis robot.
And WAKFU is a masterpiece.

reviewText: Wakfu is a turn based MMORPG with a crafting system, political system and ecological system. There are multiple classes to choose from, all unique, no archetypes are used, and combat is interesting, if not engaging. Party members can make or break certain dungeons and the learning curve is certainly high, but once you hit your stride, the game opens up tremendously. There are also several gathering and professions you can learn/master all of which can factor in your early game.\n\nAll the content is well thought of until you hit level 120-120 and then it all becomes irrelevant. The game has no endgame goals, PVP is pointless, token and nonexistent. The government system" doesn't actually impact your game in any way and ecological features do not factor in the endgame content. Wakfu is a semi-meaningful 70 hours followed by nothing. If you like spending time by yourself crafting
hoursPlayed: Stardew Valley or Rune Factory on DS.\n\nNow

reviewText:
I'd like to start saying my hours played isnt very accurate. I played via Wakfu launcher for much more than i did here.

This game is a remake of a popular game known as Final Fantasy Tactics. a Square grid based, turn based tactical game.

There are some great features of the game but most are overshadowed with extreme lacklustre support and game management. Ranging from hacks and exploits never being dealt with causing the entire auction house(market) to flood kamas into the game nulifying the years spent aquiring them. Top end-endgame gear being duplicated and flooding the system making them about as expensive as a level 20 set.

Even dealing with the PKing system which is an absolute joke if you run into a kiddie that has nothing better to do then camp decent leveling zones ( such as A.W) and kill you for no reason hours on end. (Which wasnt really a problem  after a while because i just Ddos'd him anytime i needed to enter the zone again so my friends and I could atleast play the game hassle free.)

Then there is the subscription issue. As a player that has been with Wakfu and Dofus for many years now and owns all DLC and content. My subscription has finally ran out and I am no longer able to enter most end-game zones to further progress my character. So I provided Wakfu with money to assist with producing new content for them to release the content and then make me pay again to play on it... Seems a bit stupid from a consumers prospective. My friends and I have now actually quit Wakfu due to extreme neglect from Management and lack of content advancements over the years.

While i DO recommend this game for a new users for a few hours to pass some time. I do not however advise you to ever pay them for their lack of service and progress and just quit once it gets a little boring after a hour or two.

PS. There is a reason the Bug and Issues" forum is bigger than the "General Disucssions" forum.."

reviewText:
Years ago, this game was roughly 5% F2P. You could hardly do anything. It was fun but so incredibly limited. Now that it's ~95% F2P, you can do pretty much everything. So far, the only thing I've seen in-game that costs real money is an account-share vault that allows you to store items to be used by all characters on your account. A huge improvement from what I saw so long ago.

The fighting style is very similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, one of my favorite games of all time. Play with friends or else you'll feel lost in this big, confusing world. You can solo but it's a lot easier with friends and the game seems to lean heavily on party play.

I'd rate this game a 9/10 with a half point deduction because of repeatition (which is in pretty much every RPG) and another half point deduction because it's not as fun to solo. I highly recommend you play with friends.

reviewText:
It was a great mmo with partial skill based leveling, full player generated economic system (the only way money appear in a game is being crafted by players), simulated ecosystem (climate, monsters and resourced depend on players behavior) and friendly adventure atmosphere, little buggy and class imbalanced, but tottaly playable.

So it was two years ago. Steam says it was released  18 sep, 2014, which is not quiete true. According to wikipedia it was released 29 feb, 2012. Now servers populations is low on all the shards, and almost every start location is empty. The thing is, this game is not supposed to play in an empty world. So Steam is kinda tricky saying it had just released.

But it's free and enjoyable without donate on low levels, so you should check it.

reviewText:
I love the game. Really do. It has the old isometric feel of old rpgs, and maintains the turn based combat with grace, hardly any part of the combat system feels clunky or out of place. Even grinding for xp (Trust me, you'll have to do that A LOT), there is a sense of achievement in beating your foe. The artstyle is really good, on par with the French TV show about it. It also has a nice diversity of classes, weapons, and fighting styles, for a free to play game. Also, DUNGEONS! There's a fantastic diversity of dungeons that help you level up, get some kick ♥♥♥ items, and are evidently made with a lot of thought and care.

Now the bad parts:
It's often a bit laggy, not enough to make you sick, but enough to annoy you after several hours of viewing it. The game as mentioned before, is incredibly grindy. They give you a few missions to get you on your feet, and then set you free. to some, that sounds like a gift, but trust me, it's a curse. Yuo get lost easily, and the map is no damn help at all, so you end up killing Bow Meows (cats) until you stumble on an adventure. They have a lot of items and dungeons that can be only unlocked by being a certain level, which is to stop new players from being stomped, but leveling up becomes so hard after level 10 that you end up forgetting about dungeons, which is a shame because they are SO FUN. Customization, one of my most important parts of an rpg, is pretty much nonexistent, so make sure to create your charater EXACTLY AS YOU WANT THEM TO LOOK LIKE becaue there is no covering your mistakes in heavy armor.

Other than that, the game is a really good time waster. Even though it gets very dull quickly, I find that I keep coming back to it, and I've made it a bit of my daily habit. Would recommend at the very least, try it. If you don't like it, the uninstall button exists for a reason.

reviewText: I really love this game, I also played the original one (not from Steam, the one from Ankama). The Steam-version lacks some sounds, what is a bit disappointing because they, too, made the fights and so on more interesting. What's bothering me is that I had an Ankama account before and linked it with my Steam account. Now it seems like I can't get any achievements on Steam for the things my character (that I already played before linking the Ankama account with the Steam account) does.\nSummed up, it's still a pretty awesome game but it lacks some stuff that the original from Ankama has. I'd really recommend it because it's fun to play and lets the players their freedom, the classes are interesting and if you know the series you're pretty much in heaven. Let's keep our hopes up that the lacks I mentioned before won't bother us for too long.

reviewText: Wakfu.  What to say about this game?  Tactical combat?  Check.  Cute, anime inspired graphics?  Check.  15 unique classes?  Check.  Awesome art style?  Check.  Dungeons?  Check.  The list goes on and on.\n\nThis game has personality by the boat load.  It was originally released in 2012 after a Closed Beta phase.  It is the successor to DOFUS, Ankama's other successful tactical RPG.  The games are different though.  I've never played DOFUS, but I know they're different.  If you like games like FF Tactics, then give this one a try!

reviewText:
I want to start out by saying, that if you can look past the initially grindyness of all MMORPG games, this game has a great community that you can return back to whenever. It's got great art, and wonderful music, cheezy PG-13 humor, and a great combat system.
Possibly my favorite things about this game are the fact that the four nations of the game are entirely player-run. Economy, Ecology, etc. I play as a character that makes sure other players have enemies to fight and I try to keep a good ecological balance in the places I go. New players don't seem to realize that you can actually make an enemy type go extinct, so you have to be careful. This game gets an 8.5 or a 9 out of 10 from me. Anyways, that's it for my little introductory, brief review.

Full review;
- Wakfu has an anime art style. This is because it's based around an anime of the same name, which is a french anime that, while I've personally never watched it, I do know plenty of the characters from it and I do know that it is a really rather nice anime, at least, from what I've heard from my friends. It has a great soundtrack also reminescent of the anime, and the humor is right around the same. The character designs for the game are all very solid, and even though it looks more reminescent of, say, a flashgame, where you can notice like, how the limbs move, maybe stretch, you'll notice that here, but it's in a cartoony sense so you won't pay it much mind, Id think.

- Wakfu has a very robust crafting and harvesting economy. All your resources, except for ores, are things you either have to hand-plant, or harvest from groves or gardens that are maintained by other players. Nations can impose limits to how many plants can be harvested or planted in a percentile range, and going over or below those percentiles will actually impose a penalty on you, being something as low as a 'citizen-level' penalty, to something as strict as a kill-on-sight bounty. The monster ecology for this game is exactly the same as the herb/tree/plant ecology, and everything is controlled by the players, even influencing the weather in the game for certain regions, making one region better for certain plants, and even time of years will influence the temperature!

- Wakfu's combat system is probably just as robust as it's ecological and economical parts, and I'll echo the sentiment that this game's combat system is similar to Final Fantasty: Tactic's. I can't really say too much about the current state of the combat system, as it's apparently undergone a good deal of revisions, according to my friends, and skills and passives no longer work like they used to, and work in different ways, but the combat system is still very in depth, and you can view all of it's workings, majorly, in your own character screen, so it may be intimidating at first, but the more you play around with it the more you get used to it. I'm not a very serious combative player so I can't fully explain how the combat system works, but there are a lot of classes for you to try out and tinker with, so there's probably at least one playstyle for you to like!

- On Wakfu's community.. I'm going to make one thing clear; Every game will have it's people who are there to ♥♥♥♥ with other players. This game is no different, and there's no exceptions. Players from hostile nations can invade your nation and try and instigate you to attack them, or deforest your region you're in. They can also try and bring your nation's enemy population down, but that's majorly it, people can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but a major group of people are either rather kind and helpful or they keep to themselves, which is understandable. This game shines in my opinion for how it's all player run, and you, yes, you could be nominated for helping whichever country you join, or even ruling it, if you make enough friends and prove yourself to be worth of such a responsibility. It's daunting at first, but you'll meet plenty of people who've played as leaders or as parts of nations. It's like, a half-sort of roleplaying thing, half nation management for your role. I've never been a member of a nation's staff, but I plan on working my way to that.

(I'm currently reinstalling this game, and the game's done-- for now, this is my review, but I will add more later!)

reviewText:
To be quite honest, when I first looked at this game online just after it came out, when it wasn't even on Steam, I didn't think too much of it. I thought I would try it out to see whether it was good. It did NOT turn out to be just another boring MMORPG!

This game offers you to choose between many different classes with completely different battle and playing styles and it gives large variety in choice of character build and creation!!! You are very quickly allowed to go through a tutorial that introduces you as the player to the game and gives you the run through the game. After that is finished, the character instantly starts a questline that can unlock, and make it easier to go to, new and different areas! These many and different areas have levels at which they can unlock more questlines to allow you to progress through the game and get legendary, epic and other amazing items and trinkets that help.

Not only is there all of the fun provided, but there is also quite a consistent PvP system that can rank you up quickly in fighting other players and give you useful rewards!!!

If that didn't get your attention, the creators honestly keep making and putting out Bonus XP weekends, awesome exclusive offers and purchases at the online website shop, and they certainly keep you busy with the ability to play three characters on the same account (Heroes), as well as use loads of sidekicks to help you out!

If you're not intrigued, oh well! I've loved this game since day one, even if I haven't had a load of time because of occassional barriers (Bear in mind that I've played much more on the normal launcher and not just the hours shown on my Steam account). However, it keeps you updated as much as possible, makes fun events and allows people to do their thing. The ONLY problem I found with this game is the 'required' purchase of Booster Packs to access the FULL contents. Although it shouldn't matter to most people, seeing as how most features are very much playable by anyone!

Whether you're a loyal player coming back for more, or a newbie...Play this game if you find this cool, and if not, then go find something else!!!

reviewText:
Been playing this game all day and I only have a few gripes that are overwhelmingly outweighed by the positives.

Cons:
1. Up until level 10 or so there are some really annoying quests but that's expected out of an MMO. There's one specifically which has you pushing flower pots into plants in some sort of puzzle that I find mind numbingly stupid.
2. The professions are an amazing part of the game but there is no mission or anything that really explains any of them. You have to track down the trainers themselves and read the little mini books the give you on each profession.
3. The starter area is way overpopulated and makes grinding out some of the lower levels/gear grinding kind of annoying.

That's the only real gripes I have, now, for the positives.

Pros:
1. When they game says it has unique classes it really means it. I found myself making quite a few new characters just for the sake of trying out the classes. One that sticks out in my mind is the Escaflip which is a gambling class in a since. Certain skills in the class (namely the Earth" path) are 100% based on pure luck. There are passives that make you luckier but I just find the class overall interesting.
2. The amount of stuff to do fresh out of tutorial is amazing. Immediately what came to mind is runescape just on a smaller
date: better scaled version. Including the gathering
hoursPlayed: etc. which brings me to pro number 3\n3. This one will vart from person to person depending on who you ask but I do not find the gathering to be tideous or boring

reviewText:
8/10 It's a great game for people who like challenges and don't mind being social in a video game and can tolerate easy grinding.

General Census
I like it, it has this cute unique charm that you don't often see in free to play's. The gameplay has very much depth on comparable terms to when ragnarok was popular before transitioning to 3D. For somebody who has watched the show on both seasons, I can say this is very faithful to the wakfu IP, especially if you like old video game references and culture.
It is a very artsy game for something than runs on java and is sprite based.

Gameplay
The game itself is very hardcore in terms of rpg's where you need to number crunches and research on having the ideal build for character’s. The gameplay is more forgiving in a sense compared to the old days where everything was un-killable without organized efforts. It is sandbox but it has some sense of direction, every so often you will get a quest giving you an idea of what you should be doing at this point.

However the professions in the game and the drops give it a very strong grindy feeling, but it doesn't hurt so much because of how easy it is too grind. They give you several options and ways on how to level professions so you don't get bored or annoyed instantly.

It's very easy instead of being this long gradual process, not to mention how fast you can level up. In each battle they give these conditions in the upper left which are rule sets, and if follow them no matter how confusing they can be you will get some insane bonuses. Me and a buddy have been playing this since Friday, and we reached the 30's bracket with just 6 hours of game time each day in-between this game and dark souls. And we came from games like WoW and Guild wars where everything was boring and repetitive.

These rules are unique challenges and make everything more challenging because we are purposely putting handicaps on ourselves to get the best rewards. And the xp and drop rates are astonishing if you follow through, I used to beta test this game back in 2011 before they came to steam and I dropped it because of how much of a chore everything in the game was.

They have these little Gatcha machines outside of dungeons and depending on your performance in them you get these tokens to use on the machines so if you trying to build a set, you just go to this little machine and use the tokens you earned to finish the set.

Ups
Ankama did some really good revamps and permeantly removed that paywall, everything is there for free to play and the gap between people who get boosters are very little because it just a time saver. There are some annoying options like not being able to deposit money or items in an account bank and have it spread across all characters, and having limited bag spaces;  But is solved if you just make bags or buy them off the market boards.

This may be one of the first games I played where they made the environment an integral part of the game because when you cut down trees, harvest plants, or kill mobs. These things don't respawn. You have to do your part and befriend nature by collecting seeds, planting trees, and breeding monsters so you can the players around you have access. You get rewards and points by helping the environment and give your character a reputation on how helpful you are to the people around you.
Everyone is rewarded for not being selfish and increasing this collaboration between people.

The last part I’m going to cover is the politics system and how it affects people who join nations. The people in seats of power are given the reasonability of making sure everyone in their territories is looked after. They spend their cash and collect taxes to buy bonuses which apply to everyone in their nation and their lands by having increased drop rates, more natural resources available to use, and giving access to dungeons that are not normally open for everyone. They also organize the pvp structure for the lands and against other nations.

They pass laws protecting the environment and reward those who plant and expand dwindling resources. And give people titles for those who go out of their way to give security to the people that serve their realm. Everyone has a part to play to guarding lands against thieves and invaders, to distributing crafting materials and giving to the less fortunate or under leveled.

Downs
The game is confusing at times and does not always explain what you need to do, I had to use the wakfu encyclopedia from time to time to figure out where stuff is, what drops what, and how to get things. It is also very weird on how sensitive things are for spells, victory conditions, quest conditions, and crafting conditions.

There was an instance where I had to capture and tame a wild giant turkey, and was given 3 books which actually do nothing for me in terms on capturing it. They gave me a book on how to eat these things when I am supposed to capture one and use it as a mount, so I do not know why they would tell me how to eat my mount. I have to talk to a guy inside the pen and had to make sense of his explanation.

One of the problems I have with the game is that I don't want to sit and read a bunch of paragraphs, and by not doing so I am punished by not giving me something intuitive. I constantly need to read stuff otherwise I won't know what I’m doing and I don't play video games to read things, I don't mind cut scenes and people telling stories but it’s kind of hard to enjoy the game if I am constantly reading everything. I won't give them ♥♥♥♥ for not narrating anything but it would be a nice change of pace if they gave small tutorials with a over voice explanation so you’re not constantly consulting manuals or googling.

reviewText:
The game itself is quirky, beautiful, and addictive. The classes are completely unique, and each has four different elements it can focus in, which makes for a lot of easy tailoring to play style.

Even though it's the most aethetically pleasing MMO out there, it's still infested with middle schoolers learning their first swear words. It's an interesting sight to have some grouchy kid stomp the plants you're growing for a recipe while cussing you out, saying your flowers are too close to theirs. If you were expecting this game to have a nicer commmunity, boy, are you naive.

Luckily, you can pick and choose which chat channels you see through buttons on the right of the chat box. You can have groups and guilds and the like, but I have become a hermit and still find the game fascinating.

reviewText: I played Dofus for years. I always said that Dofus is great game and you won't ever find game like Dofus. How wrong I was. Wakfu is like evolved Dofus. Sure it lacks some things we didn't even know we like in Dofus (e.g. you don't get all skills at once so you have more time to learn using them), but generally Wakfu is even better. Why is Wakfu so special? You have to use your brain while fighting. Of course you will have some skill pattern, few skills you will use again and again, however you have to know where to go, who should be killed first, etc. New monster means new type of battle. And another great thing Wakfu offers to its players is economy and ecosystem. There are no NPCs for buying/selling, everything is on players. Another thing, that depends on players is nature. You can gather plants, you can cut trees, but if you want them to grow again, you have to plant them. And monsters as well. Also everyone in certain area can get bonus, because special NPCs who take care of areas will tell you how much trees they want there, how much monsters, ... And if they are pleased, players get temporary bonus stats. I am not saying everyone will love the game, but I think everyone should at least try.

reviewText:
Wakfu is a turned based MMORPG, that has interesting graphics, music, so on and so forth with things that've already been touched on.

Lemme tell you about the part of it that really makes ME excited. Wakfu really tried to build a world that was entirely dependent on the people who play it. So, right off the bat? There are zero NPCs, aside from the occasional quest giver. That means if you're looking to sell your ♥♥♥♥, you better start up a stand. There's also an Ecology system that effects monsters and gathering nodes (trees, plants, ore, etc.) wherein, if you kill too much, or take too much, it'll actually GO AWAY. It's up to the player to repopulate these areas by planting things, breeding animals and generally working with the Wakfu" of any particular area.

Some other notable parts are as follow: Player elected governors
date: citizen points that can effect how the world treats you (Wanna be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
recommended: be an outlaw and go to jail? Hell yeah you do.)
hoursPlayed: instant player housing (Haven bag) that... also works as your store
voteText: a place to decorate things
helpfulPercent: a place to put gathering nodes and so on. There's also huge maps
votesHelpful: the ability to spec into every kind of profession
votesTotal: interesting character classes that have little to no over lap as far as utility... I mean
votesFunny: come on!\n\nI'll admit I'm pretty stoked about this game. However
commentsCount: it is definitely not a game for everyone. The combat can be pretty off putting
column16: and it's generally not as fun of an experience if you go at it alone. But
column17: if you're the type of person that really likes to see a game take some amazing steps for MMOs
column18: you might wanna give this a shot."
