reviewText:
8/10 It's a great game for people who like challenges and don't mind being social in a video game and can tolerate easy grinding.

General Census
I like it, it has this cute unique charm that you don't often see in free to play's. The gameplay has very much depth on comparable terms to when ragnarok was popular before transitioning to 3D. For somebody who has watched the show on both seasons, I can say this is very faithful to the wakfu IP, especially if you like old video game references and culture.
It is a very artsy game for something than runs on java and is sprite based.

Gameplay
The game itself is very hardcore in terms of rpg's where you need to number crunches and research on having the ideal build for character’s. The gameplay is more forgiving in a sense compared to the old days where everything was un-killable without organized efforts. It is sandbox but it has some sense of direction, every so often you will get a quest giving you an idea of what you should be doing at this point.

However the professions in the game and the drops give it a very strong grindy feeling, but it doesn't hurt so much because of how easy it is too grind. They give you several options and ways on how to level professions so you don't get bored or annoyed instantly.

It's very easy instead of being this long gradual process, not to mention how fast you can level up. In each battle they give these conditions in the upper left which are rule sets, and if follow them no matter how confusing they can be you will get some insane bonuses. Me and a buddy have been playing this since Friday, and we reached the 30's bracket with just 6 hours of game time each day in-between this game and dark souls. And we came from games like WoW and Guild wars where everything was boring and repetitive.

These rules are unique challenges and make everything more challenging because we are purposely putting handicaps on ourselves to get the best rewards. And the xp and drop rates are astonishing if you follow through, I used to beta test this game back in 2011 before they came to steam and I dropped it because of how much of a chore everything in the game was.

They have these little Gatcha machines outside of dungeons and depending on your performance in them you get these tokens to use on the machines so if you trying to build a set, you just go to this little machine and use the tokens you earned to finish the set.

Ups
Ankama did some really good revamps and permeantly removed that paywall, everything is there for free to play and the gap between people who get boosters are very little because it just a time saver. There are some annoying options like not being able to deposit money or items in an account bank and have it spread across all characters, and having limited bag spaces;  But is solved if you just make bags or buy them off the market boards.

This may be one of the first games I played where they made the environment an integral part of the game because when you cut down trees, harvest plants, or kill mobs. These things don't respawn. You have to do your part and befriend nature by collecting seeds, planting trees, and breeding monsters so you can the players around you have access. You get rewards and points by helping the environment and give your character a reputation on how helpful you are to the people around you.
Everyone is rewarded for not being selfish and increasing this collaboration between people.

The last part I’m going to cover is the politics system and how it affects people who join nations. The people in seats of power are given the reasonability of making sure everyone in their territories is looked after. They spend their cash and collect taxes to buy bonuses which apply to everyone in their nation and their lands by having increased drop rates, more natural resources available to use, and giving access to dungeons that are not normally open for everyone. They also organize the pvp structure for the lands and against other nations.

They pass laws protecting the environment and reward those who plant and expand dwindling resources. And give people titles for those who go out of their way to give security to the people that serve their realm. Everyone has a part to play to guarding lands against thieves and invaders, to distributing crafting materials and giving to the less fortunate or under leveled.

Downs
The game is confusing at times and does not always explain what you need to do, I had to use the wakfu encyclopedia from time to time to figure out where stuff is, what drops what, and how to get things. It is also very weird on how sensitive things are for spells, victory conditions, quest conditions, and crafting conditions.

There was an instance where I had to capture and tame a wild giant turkey, and was given 3 books which actually do nothing for me in terms on capturing it. They gave me a book on how to eat these things when I am supposed to capture one and use it as a mount, so I do not know why they would tell me how to eat my mount. I have to talk to a guy inside the pen and had to make sense of his explanation.

One of the problems I have with the game is that I don't want to sit and read a bunch of paragraphs, and by not doing so I am punished by not giving me something intuitive. I constantly need to read stuff otherwise I won't know what I’m doing and I don't play video games to read things, I don't mind cut scenes and people telling stories but it’s kind of hard to enjoy the game if I am constantly reading everything. I won't give them ♥♥♥♥ for not narrating anything but it would be a nice change of pace if they gave small tutorials with a over voice explanation so you’re not constantly consulting manuals or googling.

reviewText: honestly, this is pretty fun, it's a player driven ecosystem, meaning players who focus on different jobs, such as farmer, handyman, trapper etc. you also have a TON of classes to mess with, from the gambling ecaflips, to the situation changing masquaraiders, to the speedy portal summoners the eliotropes and a ton more, while you can have more then one job in the ecosystem, you will need help finding the items needed for some stuff, personally I recommend playing this game with a band of friends so you can all get a lot of stuff done and have a blast during the battles, which are freaking fun as hell, honestly, the only reason I would not recommend this game, is if your not a fan of grinding for stuff, or don't have a lot of time to spend, so for me, this game gets a solid, but not perfect, 8/10

reviewText:
A few key things to know about this game.

1.) You will do a LOT of grinding.

2.) The end game dungeon currently requires you to pay to even ACCESS. (No sub means the highest level area is locked out for you.

3.) If you pay money you get to field more heroes/sidekicks allowing subs to monopolize more turns per fight

4.) PvP is dominated by people who have sunk hundreds, if not thousands of hours into the game, even with subscriptions. If you plan on doing any serious pvp, it won't be until your AT LEAST 1,000 hours into the game. Until then be prepared for a lot of repetition.

If one of these points don't turn you off then you might want to check the game out. Mechanically it isn't bad and the community, for the most part are a cool bunch of people. That said, around 120-140 prepare to spend hundreds of hours running the same 1-2 dungeons fighting the same group of mobs over and over again. Unless you can join a guild to find people who will help pass the repetitive nature of the game it will eventually get to you.

NOT FOR LONE WOLF PLAY - PERIOD

reviewText: The game itself is very dull and slow paced. Tactical RPGs should never be MMO's to begin with and the game has very little driving aspect to get the players to play the game. That being said it still has unique features and fun gameplay mechanics that is better suited for single player. You can play single player in the game by building a bunch of characters and then sidekick them to your main character (with the only fatal flaw being you have to spend over 25$ just to even do that for 90 days). I like where Ankama is going with this but they are doing it the wrong way. They should do what Squaresoft did when they made Final Fantasy Tactics for the Playstation 1. If they were to do that and sell the game for roughly 20$ on steam than they would be able to have a successful video game. If people like tactical RPGs, this game will be up your alley. Just a note though: Game is kind of buggy and not many players to play with.

reviewText:
Wakfu, I kind of recommend the game, the free build allows you to make the character any way you want,
beside may not have skills for that kind of gameplay.

The world in the game is big, and there are quests and events that pop up randomly that gives you experience,
you can also help the world be populated with monsters and flora, or even destroy it, depending on what you do,
you can even gain a few good points to your nation.

There is also the crafting system on the game, where you can create items and weapons that may be usefull
for you, and the better, you can learn all kinds of crafting at the same time, so no cap of what you can specialize on.

The only cons I found on the game are:
Look's like attacking with the player equipped weapon is weaker than using skills on the enemy, even more because
weapon attack can only be used once per turn, but skills, depending on them, can be used twice or more in a turn, causing higher dps.

The faction war system is the most vile system I've ever saw in a game, beside it seems like not having much impact
on the game world, it impossibilitates you of visiting other towns, because if you cross the frontier, you are screwed.

You can easily get confused when doing quests, even more because some of them are not very clear of where is the objective, so you may end up having to look on the web where is the quest objective.

Beside those cons, the game is fun, but not really my type of game, even more because playing alone may make you get tired of it very quickly.

reviewText: This is one of the best MMORPGs I've ever played. The textures may not look so good if you play games for what they look like, but they've got theyr beauty. Also every single thing in this game is amazingly complex, like the ecosystem or the jobs. Damn, it even has political stuff in it if that's what you're into. Also the classes are sooooooooo varied, each with it's own huge range of unique spells that provides a ♥♥♥♥ load of combos and stuff. One more thing: the game is MASSIVE, it has tons of areas to explore and a lot of dungeons, items, jobs, quests, anything... The bad stuff? Well, if you play alone it kinda gets boring, but it's a good thing that Wakfu has this amazing comunity, everyone is so friendly and helpful and stuff, no trolls, nor scammers, so you'll make friends real fast and you'll have for sure someone to play with. In the end: great game, also free so it won't hurt to try.

reviewText:
Love the show, don't love the game.

Improvements I think that are worth my time:

*Making dungeons playable with a single character

*Balancing outside mobs      (EVEN in the STARTING AREA a level 6 and level 3 are easier to kill than a level 3 and level 5 cause the level 5 can spam heals and the level 3's AI tells it that if it gets hit run on a tile that heals every enemy, for a noob and even a returning player when your trying to do the early level grind it will kill you if you are not careful and they are the starting area mobs, like really?)

*Don't give stat point control to your player classes        (YOUR NOT DARK SOULS, you have a level cap and rng on good equipment making players rethink the points they spend constantly)

*Don't have a spell level up system if you keep having to fix it         (After playing tons of other mmorpgs, seeing a xp grind system slapped onto spells(skills) makes the game punishing when after hours of grinding you find out that one spell in your build becomes pointless and should be switched out.)

*Lower the drop rate on emotes or any cosmetic items        (If I can't play the guitar in battle then it does NOT need to instill the faith I have of the sheer chance of a werewolf trying to dry hump my leg before it ever thinks about droping.)

*Cut all the grinding for xp in half         (Oh I don't mean like get rid of the xp booster, keep those and make them give even more xp than before! I understand you got to make a living but people who can't invest in alternate characters without a booster makes them jump ship to another game.)

*Fix your REPORT FEATURE         (I think they still haven't fixed the bug that makes your computer freeze the screen almost every 5 seconds of character movement.)

Til then enjoy having the Nox server look like a ghost town. Really is looking more empty everyday I get back on.

reviewText:
Wakfu is a French tactical turn-based MMORPG by Ankama Games.
That name might ring a bell, as they are also the ones behind Dofus.

Now, Wakfu is kind of a special deal for me. I used to play it with a bunch of friends back when it was in closed beta, and still do from time to time nowadays. Why is that? Well, quite simply, because it's addictive.

Fancy stylized graphics, isometric perspective, fast yet challenging levelling, satisfying combat, microtransactions never seen ingame and do not offer any advantage, the list as to why this game is great just goes on. Additionally, it runs on low-end hardware and takes very little space, making it the perfect MMORPG to put on weak computers.

This game does have a few flaws, however. The customization is limited, it uses Java (Resulting in memory leaks) and more importantly, it just isn't as fun to play alone. If you really want to experience this game to it's fullest, having friends around is almost a requirement.

Still, I reccomend you give it a try. Install it, go on the international server (Remington, which for some reason offers free premium membership) and have a look for yourself. It's just worth it.

reviewText:
Wakfu.
The name alone makes people cringe like, you don't even want to go there.
In the beginning there was Dofus, and I'd be lying if I said all was well.
Dofus was the first of its kind, back when Steam actually made games and we were all little younglings playing 'Gunz: The duel'.
Dofus was an interesting beast because unlike conventional play to win games at the time, Dofus was an over glorified demo of an MMO back when other MMO's thought they could actually stand up to the likes of Everquest and World of Warcraft.

As time went on, many of us old guard who rememered the awful, oppressive treatment at the hands of Anakama had moved on and seemingly so had a large enough portion of the playerbase that a sequel was in order!

A strange move indeed, making a sequel only a few years after your base product had launched. Wakfu of course is that sequel.

Well it was announed years before it arrived and that signalled only the beginning of its issues. Not as late as Duke Nukem Forever but late enough to miss its own funeral because Wakfu is effectively dead.
I say effectively because the servers seem to still be online, probabaly with the funding from the first game and piggy backing on those servers too no doubt.

Dofus became a franchaise even having its own cartoon series over in France and its nice that we have a game filling this cutesy on the surface but brutally difficult when you play niche, but Wakfu is an MMO and with so few people around to play with, it just falls apart.

But lets go back in time! What about when there WERE people to play with? Dofus was still a better game! Its like they took out all the things in Dofus that demanded teamwork and made Wakfu a 1 player game with online connectivity.
Some people may like that idea but remember that this game was born from an MMO; it is akin to World of Warcraft having a World of Warcraft 2, still set in Azeroth only now its a one player twin stick shooter. It might be good on its own merits but we can't ignore the dramatic shift and we know the old crowd, the ones most likely to even want a sequal are going to feel very alienated.

That is Wakfu. Welcome to Wakfu.
Now all that aside is the game even good? Well the animations are fantastic, no really they are a joy to look at! The music...Well it exists. Yeah no one track really adds much which is a shame. The graphics are once again top notch like the animation and looking at the world around you isn't breath-taking like in Dark Souls or anything like that but they look great. Real dediction went into every art asset.

Wakfus biggest failings are not even its own fault. Communities grow and wain as new products come out to tempt the crowds. Anakama are terrible at customer support but that is more of an 'outside of the game' issue. The music might lack pepper but that is very minor indeed. Really I don't recommend Wakfu but only for 1 reason and that reason is that its old!

I don't mean old games suck, not in the least but what I mean is the community is effectively gone, its like Guildwars, which is a fantastic game, but going into Lions arch and having no one to play with, well it is the death kneel for an MMO" and while people are playing Wakfu
date: the vast community has long since moved on and when I played I found barely anyone to interact with
recommended:
even my screenshots were barren of life when I took them.

What a shame.
If you and enough of your friends can populate the game
hoursPlayed: you may have fun. If however you are looking to play this game in order to make new friends then move on

reviewText:
I'd heard about this game before, and decided to give it a shot.  Between the absolutely terrible tutorial on my first session, and the failure to connect through steam on my second session, I don't recommend it.   The characters are cute, but as with many MMO's, the story is so nonexistent as to be pointless.  Whether RPG or tactical, I come to an MMO for the story.  That story should be something that engages ME, and the character I've created, too, not just some authors' buttpatting himself and his side characters.  I should know my character's role in the game, and what the plot basis is, within the first ten minutes of playing.  In that regard, this is a complete failure.  I played for over and hour, and had no idea.  I finally got to a cinematic, and it wouldn't play.

What I've seen of the anime is also so deeply geared toward making you want to play the game, that it burns the heart and soul out of anyone who loves animation in its own right.  The anime is to this game, what My Little Pony was to their toys, back in the 80's.  It's just self-aggrandizing garbage, made SOLELY TO GET CHILDREN TO BUY INTO A PRODUCT LINE.  It's the kind of thing that knocks the world of animation to the stone age.  In a period where there are a ton of folks trying to elevate animation into an art form and a craft, people are still shoveling out cartoons like Wakfu, which exist only to be advertisements, and they destroy the credibility those people have worked so hard to build.  Shame on everyone with their hands on it!  The art is beautiful, I won't lie, but they essentially sold their soul, and far too cheaply, at that.

If you're feeling in an MMO mood, go play WoW, EVE, or Guild Wars 2.  You want FFT style tactics, then just go replay FFT.

reviewText:
I don't have any play time Via Steam because I've been playing it for months via Ankama.
This is an extremely fun game, with quite a lot to do. from dungeons to professions, challenges, quests, and its getting bigger and better every day, While the customer support at times is lacking. the game is amazing. full of comedy, and also peverse sense of humor can be found in almost everything, from the monsters drops to the equipment, some of them are just outlandish, take a look at the Tofu Rump monster drop if you don't believe me, its a literaly A hole lol.

The game has a political system, with an ever changing ecology for every zone, containing plants, crops, tree's ore and mosnters. all of which are depleted / maintained through players, and naturally occuring reproduction ( you can watch some Gobball / Tofu porn while you wait for spawns :D lols ) and a weather system, while not entirely visual, its presentm and affects growth rates of plants.

all in all, I would very readily reccomend this game for anyone interested in an mmorpg with tactical grid based combat.

The game has a political system, with an ever changing ecology for every zone, containing plants, crops, tree's ore and mosnters. all of which are depleted / maintained through players, and naturally occuring reproduction ( you can watch some Gobball / Tofu porn while you wait for spawns :D lols ) and a weather system, while not entirely visual, its presentm and affects growth rates of plants.

all in all, I would very readily reccomend this game for anyone interested in an mmorpg with tactical grid based combat.

reviewText:
I just recently quit this game after playing since open beta about 4 years ago. ( only played though steam a lil bit)

This is the grindiest game I have ever played, if you want stuff you have to spend weeks farming it.  Unless you buy duped gear which is all the rage at the moment.

The community is either casual, fun to play with people who are high on painkillers, or hardcore players with the mentality of ' who needs friends when you can play 6 accounts and get all the loot!'

For what though?  PvP is not fun at all in this game and hard to find.  Most people with their pvp wings up will just have a counter build waiting for you after the fight so if you dont play with 6+ accounts you are at a huge disadvantage.   Then theres the merit farmers who just pvp themselves for points so the ranking system is a complete joke.

There really is no reason to play this game unless you wanna feel like a complete dweeb playing a multiplayer game BY YOURSELF with 6 accounts.  Or if you are heavily medicated and need an endless supply of things to click over and over while your life slips through your fingers.

reviewText:
I gave this game a fair chance--I truly did. It has its own unique charm and somewhat unique gameplay elements. There are many job classes--and I do mean many with tons of specializations you can consider by spending your precious skill points in one skill tree or another. You can even bash the tarnation out of other players via pvp at any time in the open world environment--even from the start of the game (once past the tutorial area).

However, there are so many other mmorpgs out there that this one gets lost in the crowd and there are some incredibly frustrating elements to the game's structure. First off, it seems to be programmed exclusively in Flashplayer and uses a point-and-click interface to get the character to do anything. So you will be constantly using a mouse for everything. Leveling crafts, crafting gear, grinding, it gets to be so tedious with such a clunky interface after a while that I honestly just stopped with the other aspects of the game and tried focusing on leveling just to try and keep going.

One of the main features of the game though is political and other players seem to constantly beg you for one thing or another--or even worse: they attack you because you belong to a different faction than them. Unfortunately, there's no way to simply stay factionless in the game either--it makes you choose one to progress past certain points and areas in the game.

I honestly gave this game a go because I thought it would be something completely different--and it was: a nightmare. If you like a game with entirely too much going on then maybe this one might be for you. Otherwise you might want to skip this one. (And yes, I kept this review general on purpose without going into any spoilers--you're welcome XD)

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential. Too bad it doesn't make any use of it.

The combat is fun. It's different than what most games do, it's pretty tactical. It lasts you for about 2 days, because it gets repetitive fast.


Why? Well there are a lot of classes, they are pretty different from each other, you can really find one for you. Each class has 3 branches of abilities, depending on element you will be using.

While you have up to 15 active abilities you will only use about 2-3(at most) from them, since there aren't many situational skills, there are just those that do more and less damage. You don't want to mix abilities between branches, because that means less damage(best gear gives element based +%damage). Skills in the same branch usually have the same range, so you're stuck with either long range or close combat once you choose. And that's not a bad thing right? Well, no, but once again, you're stuck with using 2 skills because the others deal less DPS.

It doesn't help that you kill the same enemies over and over again, because the game is so empty that finding a group for a dungeon is nearly impossible, except for the most popular dungeons, and even then it's problematic.
Most people meet in starter area,which is pretty populated. After you get to your nation, you're pretty much playing single player with someone passing you by every once in an hour.


At least the crafting system looks nice, after choosing to become an area of effect weapon smith I was greeted with message that I won't be able to harvest materials, and will have to buy them from lumberjacks and miners.
Wish I had some kind of warning before I chose my profession, but okay, I'm fine with that, the system looks great! This means that what I make will surely have buyers, because if you're a lumberjack you won't be able to make those weapons. If you're a baker you will buy my weapons and I will buy your bread. That's awesome! Finally someone did it right.

Except I still could harvest. I could chop down the trees and gather iron ore from deposits. I could learn all the professions and create anything I needed myself.


Instead of having good economy based on supply and demand, they screwed it up completely. You want to be a baker? Well you better be a farmer too, because otherwise you would have to pay for the flour.




It's fun for about 2 days, after that you have tried all classes, finished the Astrub(starter zone) quests 10 times, and there's no point in moving to main land, since there's no people there.

That's a shame.

reviewText:
I tried, I really tried to get into this game. But here is my perspective:

The game is quite nice but I do not reccomend this to brand new players. It really is not new player friendly, and the dungeons are very difficuly for new players. You need patience to play this game.

It is turn based, and the combat system is unique but what made me (as a new player) leave this behind were:

Dungeons that are puzzle based, really give you zero hints on how to beat it. You are forced to use google on this and you cannot leave a battle unless you quit the game. Other tactical based mmos allow an escape" feature if the battle is too tough or you need to leave
date: this however does not.  This right here is a red flag for me.\n\nAnother feature that didn't really keep my interest is the quest system. For new players
hoursPlayed:
you have to manually try to find your quest destination as most do not give you a compass (quest tracking tracing feature).

So in summary:

Pros
____

Unique battle system
Tons of classes
Small Patch and Download

Cons
____
Not new player friendly.
Map layout can be confusing for new players.
Google how to beat puzzle dungeons (new players).
No hints on puzzles from in-game.
Can't leave in the middle of a battle without logging out. (no escape or flee chance option).

Overall: Do tons of research and look up guides if you are new to Wakfu. If you are a veteran
voteText: then jump right in.\n\nNew player perspective: 3/10"

reviewText:
A charming game - initially.
Cash shop is more cosmetic than gameplay - except for boosters to xp and drops.

Combat is a plus , its highly tactical , full of MANY skills  with a broad array of tactics to use depending on the skills you choose to develop. Many different stats affect gameplay.

There are no NPC's. Players will have to barter or trade for any ingame currency. This can be a blessing or a curse depending how it is implemented in a game and how a games economy is setup. In wakfu , this is a curse.

Wakfu suffers from an extraordinarily handicapped economic system. There is a central auction house however most things cost 1-20 / ea , ingame currency. If those things are even listed. It is cavernously empty most of the time. Many items run 20,000 - 20,000,000. Prices vary wildly , not because of some economic principle , but because there is a large glut of equipment left over from those whom are Leeched" through most of the games levels to level 105 by already established guilds. If your a new players who does not wish to interact with or play marco polo trying to discover who the major guilds are - Good luck.  The player base is sharply divided between old veteran players (commanding in some instances hundreds of millions of ingame currency)
date: whom are largely silent and meandering new players who dont seem to understand what todo or where togo and whom appear to be largely confused.\n\nLeveling is fun ....... the first 50 times you encounter mobs.  Once you realize exactly how much grinding is entailed you begin to understand the presence of xp pots in the ingame item mall - and why new players are encouraged simply to quit the game if they cant find an active guild which they can tag along with during higher end repetitive runs. Seriously
recommended: I was told this several times.\n\nRespec'ing your character? Is considered an act of god in this game. An occassion so special that it requires no less than 1400 items spread across 8 different mob types which must be killed to gather at a pace of about 1-3 per encounter (Not kidding). Even THIS can only be done every 30 days.  Act of god? Or act of marketing? You decide.  Oh and if your a new player - you can expect these encounters to last anywhere from 5-10 mins
hoursPlayed: EACH.\n\nFor a game as complex as wakfu is with so many different tactics to try - to have such a choke hold on simply redistributing points you earned through gameplay is rediculous in the least in my opinion. It is clearly a money grabbing effort.  Almost no information is available for many of the classes
voteText: many posts date back to 2012 - some so far as 2011 - so one is never sure whether the information you are getting is upto date or not.  The game is updated semi-frequently however
helpfulPercent:
going so far as to literally change the stats on sets of armor between updates***     Have fun with that!



Despite all of this?  Im still playing it. Glutton for punishment? Likely."

reviewText:
The anime for this game is great and explains a lot about the lore and class' but the game is far more difficult than what it lets on to be.

First off the game is loaded with bugs and not the kind that can help the player early game.

Secondly the begining quests are a tad bit far apart in levels as when i got to level 5 they sent me on a level 10 quest.

Honestly this game could use a lot of work but how it is now i cannot reccomend it to anyone unless they enjoy mindless level grinding after each quest.

On a more personal note that i do not let spoil my reviews; i hate games that let you customize your stats each and every level rather than the game just giving you whats balanced as to me that says the developer got lazy with the game

reviewText: This game is at best ok.  It has a big learning curve, a lot of glitches, and a very beta test feel.  I don't think the designers can keep up with the their ideas honestly.  Great concept and cute designs too, but so very many problems with a Java runtime game.  Alos, the store.  Expensive.  Sure, its free to play.  But you get next to no inventory space, chest space, and crafting requires a lot of items to make anything more complicated than level zero items.  Worth a play, a lot of room to grow, but I don't think the makers have any plans to.

reviewText:
It's REALLY good. There's several classes to choose from, pets, sidekicks, mounts, different armours, taunts, weapons and a large level tree, crafting options and tons and tons of professions. Quests are varied and in depth, there's a voting system on who's in charge, different areas, dungeons and so on. You can even team up with other players for better item drops and more xp.

When animals and plants are killed/harvested, you need to replant them, teaching the player how to look after and keep the ecosystem in check.

Only problem is, achivements are bugged, and dont unlock.

The characters also look cute. ^w^

reviewText:
My review will simply be about things I wish people had told me before I clicked 'install' on this:

1.) THERE ARE NO VENDERS TO SELL JUNK TO. Too much junk? Throw it on the ground. Click 'Ok' on popup. Did it have a little hammer icon on it? Whoops, looks like it was needed to craft some crap somehow. No big deal, was probably 1 of 90 of the item needed.

2.) GOOD LORD THERE IS A LOT OF CRAFT GRINDING. Let's say you wanted to wanted to make a 'Ham Sandwich' so you got +2% damage for 15 minutes (in a turn-based game). In WoW, you'd butcher some mobs and buy some salt and then cook over a fire pit and *BAM* 'Ham Sandwich' ... but not Wakfu. Nope. Go grind mining until you mine raw salt, make 3 raw salt into Refined Salt' and then go out in the field and skin some mobs for meat. Hope you leveled skinning! Go farming for wheat. Make 3x wheat into flour. Draw some water. Bake the bread. Cook the Sandwich. Each of those skills

reviewText:
Seems to be alright. There aren't enough games in the same style as Final Fantasy tactics.

However, this game seems to be one of those that is rather selective in where it plays.

As several other people exclaimed, this game does not even start after clicking the shortcut on Desktop. On my end, my PC even froze up and stopped responding until I hard-reset'd it.

I'd have loved to test it, but no game is worth it having my PC freeze up for an undetermined amount of time.

reviewText:
The game was ok when it first came out I've sunk hundreds of hours into it but with each new patch comes new bugs and suprisingly enough the issues i had when i first started playing are still around today such as immense lag. The delay in my text appearing on screen is almost 5 minutes long you dont want to know what its like in a battle.

I don't have these issues in any other games other then wakfu even their prior game Dofus which has been around for 10 years isnt laggy.

How this got on Steam i will never know.

They keep bringing out more new cool things with each update but never actually work on the current issues not to mention their customer service is absolutley shocking. Countless threads have been made in the forum regarding issues with the game and they have gone unheard or simply ignored for YEARS! There is an issue that every person has ingame where they will start to freeze up at around the 3 hour mark of playing if not sooner. But as ankama doesnt bother fixing this long time running issue the players see it as a normal thing and actually accept that they have to restart their client every hour or two just to keep playing.. What if your in a high level dungeon and all of a sudden start experiencing these freezes. I know for a fact my guildmates have become frustrated to the point where they quit as have I.

I came back to check it out as I saw it was on Steam but I am very dissapointed.

The game has picked up in popularity due to its Steam release but alas I still think its not worth the time invested, As like me you will get a high(ish) level character invest money in the game and then it slaps you in the face and becomes unplayable.

Also purchase Ogrines at your own risk there are multiple reports of people not recieving their Paid for Currency and as Ankama take so long to reply you may be waiting over a week to hear back.. I literally yesterday recieved a response to a ticket I posted LAST YEAR!

reviewText:
Do not bother with this piece of trash. I know this comes off as incredibly negative review but I was trying to curb my frustration with this game for the simple reason that I REALLY wanted to like this game. The genre is SO rare to find a good version of it that isn't plagued by utter stupidity.

The BIGGEST and most SACRELIGIOUS issue with this game is the TIMER. Don't EVER make a tactics game with a timer. There's NEVER a reason to do this and it just rushes things.

Now ... this wouldn't have been such a massive issue if it wasn't for the fact that everything is SO hard to understand. The translations aren't HORRIBLE, but the descriptions are rather ... vague and subpar. They make figuring out how abilities work and effect function more trial and error than actual reading and understanding. Which is made harder by a short turn timer.

Then you have an opening tutorial that does nothing to grease new players into the game. This will be a grindy game, from beginning to end. And in all the weirdest ways. Grinds in the typical ways of course too, but weird ways like forcing yourself to learn a new game that fights against you because the genre is so promising and the like.

It's very painful to see such a pretty game turn me away because of simple, outright, horrible execution. I sometimes wonder after playing a game like this .... Do these people even play their own game?

reviewText:
Wakfu is a turn-based MMORPG, with a great variety of characters and builds, and a heavy dose of grinding.
I found the first hour enjoyable, but the tutorial leaves a lot to the imagination, and there is a steep learning curve when entering the actual game.

My main problem with the game is the combat system. In combat, there is a timer for every action, and when you're a new player, obviously you want to read what all your spells do and what your enemies are weak against, read passive buffs/de-buffs, etc. But the timer is way too short to do any of that, and seeing as you have enough action points to complete multiple attacks/spells in a go, it is a rush to complete your turn.

Secondly, the combat area is split into tiles/squares, each one accounting for 1 movement/range. Now, when casting a spell or attacking an enemy, you have to ensure that you have clear line of sight to the target, and that they are within range - which means, inside of the minimum and maximum range.

When you move your character, as there are often so many obstacles on the map, it is really hard to tell whether you will be able to attack the enemy with a spell, from the tile you are moving to. This means, if you are playing a spellcaster (and all characters have spells), you may sometimes waste a whole turn just trying to stand in a position where the enemy is in range.

There is also no basic 'attack'. You can't just hit someone. Your basic attack is determined by the weapon you are holding, and the weapon will have a predetermined attack range and attack area. For example, in the tutorial you receive an axe, this weapon attacks three squares around your character in a big sweeping motion, and if you have an ally nearby, the ally will take damage from the swing.

Basically, the combat is too complicated to have a timer, the tile system seems quite broken, and the information needed to make the learning curve less steep, is not very accessible. The tutorial itself was of no help when coming to the actual game.

reviewText:
The pace of the game is extremely slow and boring. Tactical games like this tend to have a slow pace, but the MMO nature ensures the challenge is minimized and grind is maximized, leaving a game that you have to work far too hard to get enjoyment out of.

Tutotial manages to waste time without teaching anything useful, then suddenly you need to pick a class based on pictures and a one sentence description, though there is much more detailed info given AFTER you pick a class. (or on the signposts scattered randomly in the tutorial zone.)

Visual style and story are both a jumbled mess.

Point for point stat allocation on level up with a huge number of choices and very little info on exactly what each stat does. Playing casually you are sure to mess up your character build right from the start.

Spammed by gold" sellers instantly on joining the game.

My verdict is don't believe the positive reviews. You won't enjoy this game at all if your time has any value to you."

there are many more issues with this game like classes being far too over powered( a lvl 65 getting their butt kicked by a lvl 60 that has 1000 more hp and more attack??????)

Sort your game out before you release it please! (oh and maybe instead of fine tuning class abilities to ever % you should actually try to fiix the main mechanics of your game. aswell as your servers, being dissconnected for no reason is a pain.......)

reviewText:
This game is absolutely awful. It is, without doubt, one of the worst things to ever hit the internet. I won't even go in to how ABSURDLY unintuitive it is, or how awful the entire sound scheme is. I'll just focus on this one, glaring, point that makes this game completely not worth it.

There is a tutorial mission, that will two-shot you. I understand what I am supposed to do. It's teaching you about Line of Sight, and how to avoid damage. Here's the thing though, the punishment is somewhere in the area of 15 damage, when you've got about 60 HP at this point. This is horrendous. You make a few mistakes, and you're dead. And I'll be honest, that isn't even THAT awful, but the line of sight for the attacks isn't SHOW to you! You have to run a gauntlet to an enemy, and you have FOUR chances to mess up. It's trial and error at the most ABSURD level. Your reward for finally getting to the end of the gauntlet? You get to do it again, in an even LESS defined map. It's stupid. It's awful.

If the tutorial was this horribly put together, then the game as a whole can't possibly be much better.

Oh and the kicker, at this point, you're not even allowed to be in a party to get help from somebody. In an MMO, they don't allow you to be in a party.

An MMO...where you can't party. Can I stress that enough?

Save your time, avoid this awful excuse for a game.

reviewText: Alright, I haven't invested too much time into Wakfu thus far and I can't say I want to eithier. I picked this game 'cause it  seemed like it might've been fun. It seemed like it would be different from most mmo's, or at least that was my impression, and I was right. Sorta. To start with, there are a reasonable number of classes to pick from. Although the brief descripions left me a little unsure as to what classes were actually effective in a fight. Although I've seen a bit of plot kicking around, I wasn't entirely sure what it was nor could I be ♥♥♥♥♥ to find out. The battles were kinda fun for the first two or three before the tedium set in. That was mainly because while there were a bunch of skills they only level up when you use them. Which meant that you'd only wind up using a couple that were strong enough to actually do anything. Even then I found that enemies I fought that were something I could techincally beat, especially in matches of 1v3 or more, I'd still have my ♥♥♥ handed to me. So either I'm terrible at tactics in a general sense, which I can't entirely deny, or I'm just finding all of the battles meant to be fought with other people. So to put all that in one sentence, Wakfu could actually be fun later on but I'm not willing to invest the time that seems necessary to get there.

reviewText:
Ingredients
2 large eggs
Salt and pepper
2 to 3 tablespoons shredded cheese (optional)
1/4 to 1/2 cup filling, pre-cooked if necessary (optional)
2 teaspoons unsalted butter
Minced parsley, to garnish (optional)

Equipment
Mixing bowl
Whisk
8-inch nonstick skillet
Spatula
Dinner plate

Instructions
1. Whisk the eggs: Crack both eggs into a mixing bowl. Whisk the eggs until completely combined, and season with salt and pepper. If you're adding cheese or other fillings, make sure they are prepped and nearby.
2. Warm the skillet and melt the butter: Place an 8-inch skillet over medium-high heat and melt the butter. Tilt the skillet as the butter melts to evenly coat the bottom. When the butter stops sizzling, the pan is heated and ready.
3. Pour the eggs into the skillet: Pour the whisked eggs into the skillet. Immediately tilt the pan so the eggs coat the entire bottom. The eggs should sizzle on contact; if not, continue cooking, but remember to heat the pan a little longer next time.
4. Drag and push the eggs to form waves: Use a spatula to gently drag and push the cooked eggs from the edges toward the center of the pan, making space for the uncooked eggs and forming waves in the omelette. Tilt the skillet so that the uncooked eggs flow into the open spaces.
5. Cook the omelette for 1 to 2 minutes: The omelette will finish cooking in 1 to 2 minutes. When done, the bottom will be set and the edges will look crisp. The top of the omelette should still look fairly wet and uncooked, but there will no longer be any loose, easily flowing liquid egg — the omelette will continue cooking off the heat, so finish when you think the top still seems a bit underdone.
6. Top with cheese and fillings: If using, sprinkle the cheese and fillings down the center of the omelette.
7. Fold the omelette: Fold the bottom third of the omelette over the center, and then fold the top third down. Alternatively, fold the omelette in half.
8. Slide the omelette onto a plate: Gently slide the omelette onto a plate and garnish with parsley. Eat right away while still hot.

reviewText:
Although this game has been littered with poorly written positive reviews that tell you NOTHING about this game I'm going to give you an honest review of what it's like to download this game, jump in, find your feet and then play *actual* content.

First of all, the tutorial is *okay*. It definitely doesn't need to be adjusted content wise. However, this game is over filling with broken English so DO NOT EXPECT the tutorial to help you in any deep sense; you learn this game by guessing and learning from your mistakes. It is NOT an 'intuitive' game and I've met many players higher level then me who didn't know basic stradegies that I learnt early on. Many as in several. As in 7 other players who considered themselves amazing.

Secondly, finding your feet is an awful experience. If you're a stranger to turn-based gameplay GIVE UP NOW. You're tossed into this enormous world filled with options but absolutely no sense of purpose or direction. To begin with, it can be SO immense that quiting IMMEDIATELY was a considered option. Why should I even bother with all this CRAP?". You learn  your own way and you creative your own incentive
date: which works excellently later in the game but early game it's a miserable experience. After you find your feet and get the rythm of the game it BEGINS to become amusing enough to be considered a video game. So prepare for a pretty bitter beginning phase.\n\nLastly
recommended: the in game content itself... So I've tried not to make the same mistake I've made on other MMOs. I've avoided the "grind my character to max and then quit" attitude and instead have be working on leveling up all my professions with my main level to make the game much more interesting. In fact
hoursPlayed: there has been some real "shining moment" inside Wakfu that no other game has come close to fulfilling. I mean there was a point where I was mining
voteText: skinning
helpfulPercent: farming and fighting all in my own little area and it was AWESOME FUN... to begin with. Now every bit of storage I have is totally and utterly filled with essential crafting resources all of which have an enormous amount of units (400+ thistle
votesHelpful: 500 wood
votesTotal: etc) so dropping IS NOT AN OPTION. I tried to combat this technical issue by crafting bags but the developers seem to have not considered that new players may want to try crafting as well; only assuming that you're clearly a high leveled player with tonnes of bag space because you poked enough fat mobs to have a full set of maxed capacity bags. I needed to gather 6 Royal Feathers from a very easy and low level dungeon. I ran that dungeon over 250 times over 2 days at my maximum speed. After all of that ... 5 feathers. Oh and a quest that will take 10 off of me. So really now I need 16. I am NOT willing to be put through such a f**k around for low level content
votesFunny: get real you idiots. Try PLAYING YOUR GAME instead of theorizing crap that works. "Ohh 16 feathers isn't much in theory"... WRONG. Wrong. Wrong. It's TOO much and has wasted over 16 hours of my life. For the dungeons themselves
commentsCount: they're *okay*. You fight the same mobs you come against in the world and then eventually a boss with much more HP and stats then normal. There is very little feedback to add to such a generic system. It works fine? That's all I can say. But! If you're with a friend and your friend lags out or DC's then expect a 40 second skirmish to last longer then 15 minutes (which is bloody insane to sit through) because the game will CONSTANTLY "wait" for the player for minute intervals even if the dungeon and game itself has acknowledge the player not only leaving but being offline.\n\nOverall
column16: you're basically fighting the game the entire way through JUST to enjoy small parts of it.\n\nLong story short: play something else because you'll quit most likely faster then I did."

reviewText:
In the past, Wakfu was a terrible F2P MMO. All the business model cared for was money money money. Players weren't able to get in-game currency and you weren't able to leave the newbie area unless you were a subscriber to the game.

Now everything has changed. F2P players can go to the zones that subscribers were able to go to, and monsters drop in-game currency (in the past, the only way you were able to get money as a subscriber was by minting it.)

The only downside to this is that the in-game currency minting machines are almost obsolete now unless they revamp that system somehow to make money-minting more profitable than grinding. But in the past items were much more cheaper than they were due to the fact that money HAD to be minted to order to get money. Now everything is a lot more expensive.

Overall if you like games that play like FF Tactics or FF Tactics Advance for fighting, as well as games that have job professions, and a Havest Moon like open world where you are able to plant things that grow (even monsters,) try this game out.

reviewText: This is a very fun casual MMORPG. The other players are nice, the story is interesting, the art is very cute, and the game mechanics (when they work) flow better than a lot of other games. Unfortunately, a lot of the game mechanics and coding based around events are not well though-out, which causes a lot of bugs and complaining. However, if you are looking for a fun, casual game and do not get hung up on the accessibility of the every single event (some work, some don't), this is a great game.

reviewText:
Good:
Combat is fun, especially with friends
The world is very open allowing for exploration and training your skills well beyond your level (like mining and carpentry)
All currency and item value is created and determined by the players, creating a unique market system
You can wage war on other nations with more than just pvp, you can destroy their resources as well
Being a bandit is actually helpful to other players, because they gain citizenship points for correcting your eco-terrorism

Bad:
No one usually wages war. Most of the time everyone is friends
There are no incentives to become a bandit other than for the hell of it
Game suffers from imbalanced resources (using three logs to get one plank, and using 17 planks to make a box)
experiencing minor, but consistent lag. Game seems to hickup ever couple minutes, or when pulling up the map/gathering resources
Sometimes creatures are labeled as “Busy” but aren’t doing anything, so you can’t get rid of them.

Overall, a very good game and most issues I have with it can be solved if players start trying to kill eachother in-game.
